Entry.1:
This afternoon a walk to Warloy with Toby, Murph & Bill: met there at the 14th Field base Staff Sgt. Rainsford – of the old 2nd crowd: from him hear again of Chaddy's death in the Messines stunt: and of Tal. Milford at last being drafted to the field – and what a gutzer – he's been detailed straight away to work that will tear his unlovely mind – bearing.

Chaddy I've a snapshot of – a group of five taken in the Kitchen of the 2nd at Ghezireh: they are Chadwick, Wilson, George Masters, Frank Hungerford and Jake. Jake has head garlanded with vegetables – Jake whose head and build 

call for ivy leaves or grapes.

In the cemetary – buried in long close rows between bearing fruit trees – the graves of Scotties, English, Canadians and our own boys – and in a grave of five "C. Thompson, 18 Batt. July 26, 1916, Died of Wounds." R.I.P.

Late last night, and all day today we've heard – even here so far away – heavy rolling of the big guns ….

The day's been dull, cold and the air full of rain.

Jack Bathker back today amongst latest joiners up – he was one of the squad that got knocked the second day in at Hermies – Jack, Max (still in hosp. knocked near the spine), George (back about two or three weeks) and Harry Bladin – who died of his wounds.

Wrote tonight to Phillip ler Warren for catalogue and prospectus of the "Riccardi Press" books. 'Apres la Guerre' if I can I'll get as full a collection of special press books as I can manage.
Entry.2:
2

This afternoon a walk to Buire with Silver – and a swim – and an hour in the sun, lying about the soft grass flats – then a wet again and out. Tea in the village – and a slow walk back. A summer day again after a week of cold grey rainy days. We the only ones in the river – where last week the long banks were full of the chaps of the first three Battalions: the 1st Brigade have moved about Beaumont-Hamel for a practice stunt in open order.

Today the guns heavy beyond what they've lately been.
Entry.3:
3

Across in the cowshed last night, yarning before turning in, Snow, Arthur and self. I'd mentioned "Les Miserables" and Snow started a comparison of Hugo and Dickens: it lead to other writers, and Arthur was quiet, then,

"Did y' read The Woman You Gave Me in a mag. – she's not 'arf rough – she's a snifter: if that book 'ad been a foot thick I'd 'ave read every word of it."

Then a little later,

"Gee, I'm afraid to tell you chaps what I like – you'd snout me." Then Snow, "Not – Lance." Arthur subsided with his laugh.
Entry.4:
"Hugo in England" – still cherishes after her own 1688 and our 1789 the feudal illusion. She believes in heredity and hierarchy. The people, surpassed by none in power and glory regards itself as a nation not as a people and as a people it willingly subordinates itself and takes a lord for its head. As a workman it allows itself to be disdained: as a soldier, it allows itself to be pegged.

And from what I've seen only in France, there's a deal of truth in this – ask Haggan.

But it seems certain – almost certainly certain that après la guerre this will change quickly. One of the most ironic signs of the times are the number of inanely sentimental of the press – "Queen Mary and the of Whitechapel". Queen Mary chats with the , etc. etc., and the ridiculous accounts of "Royal Visits". England without a King is not too far away from the limitless horizon.
Entry.5:
5

Yesterday to Amiens with Bus and Snow. Spent almost full afternoon in Musee de Riccardi, dinner then at de la Paix with some chap and so to Henencourt. No mail.
Entry.6: Today Harry Coffee and Tommy on leave to Blighty, yesterday Morrie and Buck back from Paris and today Bert R. back from Blighty.
Entry.7:
"Letters from France" to George C. this morning – making about the 7th to read it: "Just a little too much ---", the general opinion, but full agreement as to the writing of it, and its truth".

8. 1 p.m.

The 5th and 7th have just passed through the village marching in full Battn. order, back again afternoon, 3 p.m.
Entry.9: a.m. Now she's slowing up – not much but still the thunder is less than it was an hour or so ago: the heaviest bombardment heard since we've been here.
Entry.10:
6

Bert received from Ballarat a copy of Patterson's "Saltbush Bill, J.P.", "The Road to Hogan's Camp", the best of a very poor collection.

The end page by S. Ure Smith, the best in the small volume. There's one piece "towelling up", Lawson – not with the " snobs" which makes merely bad criticism. Lawson is far and away ahead of Patterson – he has more range and will beat P. on his own ground.

"Saltbush Bill, J.P." not by the Patterson of "Man from Snowy River" or "Rio Grande's Last Race".

11.

Today's been a day for a book beneath an orchard tree, lying in soft grass, with the loaf of bread and the flask of Muscat.

12.

Had back tooth filled – so escaped morning parade. Mail – Studio June number, and "Interior Decoration", Parsons
Entry.12:
- and the American edition: does the entry of America into the war mean their editions of English books are to be in place of English editions?

The book promises well: but the illustrations are too obviously of the American "Architectural Review" type – a type where the money behind the decorations seems to insinuate itself.
Entry.13:
Down to Buire – to the River: again the banks are full of our chaps – the first 4 Battalions. The water's cold – but the sun is perfect.

14. July 7

Today from the Commonwealth Bank letter in which note of stoppage to troops of Registered letters containing money: "by order of Military". "Well they certainly can't make us 
love
 the child" as Arthur would say.

Robbey explained letter – and offered me the money – and the making out – payable to him of a cheque for £2.10 on the Commonwealth Bank. I accepted, wrote out the cheque and wrote to Bank asking that it should be honoured. Sincerely hope this won't make any awkward situation to arise when I get at last my 'Blighty'. 

Paid Toby, also Syd.

15.

Phil Douring and self to Buire to the river for a swim and a following glorious sunbath.

16. July 8

Finishing a letter home, and one to the O.B.C. enclosing a Pound note to credit. I picked up my first journal, and read an article haphazardly. Then came across this … 201.

July 8

'Newman – till Jonas's enthusiasm – was merely a name – and a book: "The Mystery of Newman". (I'd asked J. of the "Mystery" – hence his enthusiasm.)

'Merriden got me a copy of his "Church of the Fathers": so far I've read only a few chapters. It is of the "Church of the Fathers" – of my father's – the church lost in myself.'

Then follows –

'Though essentially appealing, it revolts me in its minor points as practised by a certain class.'

The "it" used there refers to the Church doctrine – not to Newman's Book. The book I only half finished – but will some day later get it again, and read it so that the dignity of the book itself suits the beauty of its matter.

Often with Harry – before the years of war, I've yarned on the Church of the Early Christians. Harry was a Catholic of the best type – and always genuine. If he had lived – had there been no war, now I'd be again of the Church of my Father's. Yet where is the necessity of chaining belief to form? What I would gain would be the privilege of the Sacrament – that only for the knowledge of the Church and its majesty is for all.

Yet to take the Sacrament I've wished to a hundred times, but have always been afraid. With its wonder and beauty there is almost a terror about it, not a terror so much as an awfulness.

Shall I ever be of the "Church of the Fathers"?

July 8-9-10-11

17.

Today I wrote to The Studio asking particulars of two Whistler first editions – "The Tenth Art", de luxe and signed, and "Baronet and Butterfly" – the former £6 and the latter 8/6.

And the only money I possess is a borrowed £1 note – and my pay book's overdrawn.

18.

At last London Lamps – a slim booklet of verse by Thomas Burke has arrived. His two other books "Limehouse Nights" and "Nights in London" I'll get hold of later.

19. July 11

On Monday morning after parade a cable of five deadening words, Father had died on June 15 …

Yesterday I wrote to Mother and Geoff. I applied to the Col. that an application for Transport Duty be approved, so that I might do my best towards getting home - even if only for a week – to know how Mother will stand till the war is over.

I know it from the cable – just that it was on June 15 that my Father died, nothing else.

Twelve months before Harry died, and now Father and half the chaps I knew at school, dead by the war.

I can't realise it, but I know it: the cable words repeat mechanically in my mind, and for the instant I see home for a second – then the deadly blackness comes again. Mother, Betty and Geoff – and 14000 miles separate us. If I only knew their position – that Geoff will finished his school and go for his scholarship and Betty

July 11

finish her schooling. I have had my chance. Geoff shall have his.

For me here, life must go on the same – I can do nothing but wait, and then at the end of the war, or if I can get my application granted, work to move lost ground and to make up to Mother something of her loss.

And last night I remembered it, in June some time was the anniversary of 25 years marriage.

20.

General Birdwood reviewed the Amb. yesterday morning, and decorated with the M.M. Andy, Erny Brown, Lofty and Mitch.

Tomorrow the King is to review the 5th Division – on the sports ground behind the Chateau.

England leave has been added to by 16 men per week from the unit. I am down on the second list – Toby on the first.

July 11

July 12

Working since yesterday afternoon in the Orderley Room - Eric going to Rouen to study new system of bookkeeping.

21. July 12

Today Arthur Wilkinson had the word I had on Monday.

22.

The 5th Division were reviewed by the King this morning: he passed the O.R. at about midday – sitting with Birdwood.

Birdwood is a splendid type, and the chaps' favour will carry to him again.

23.

There is a rumour about that another Australian mail has been sunk, so I lose another of Father's letters, and perhaps the photographs of Mother and Betty.

24.

Leave cut down this morning to 5 every three days: and early this afternoon to 2 every three days: Tomorrow?

July 13

25.

Almost since when Brennan first appeared in his brilliantly polished badges, the spirit of the unit has been changing. The sinking ship was the 1st Field when Col. Williams took Col. Shaw's command. Col. Williams though, if he'd not been killed, would I think after his newness had worn off, have followed the example set by Col. Shaw, and after a period of transition would have put the unit again where it was when Col. Shaw commanded it. Col. Williams was wounded – and he died: Major Brennan of the 7th Field then by promotion became our C.O. – and he's made the unit spirit lower than it ever was. Till he left a few weeks ago, Maj. Wilson was the only gentleman left amongst the Officers: Capts. Lee and Hunt – both M.C.'s from the Factory Corner stunt, and since Majors follow Col. Brennan: of the new men – Maj. Frizelle - 
now with the C.R. is at Rouen acting C.O. – is as he's shown himself to us since joining up and Capt. Phillips are the only two we've got who are filling their commissions well
 and Capt. Phillips are the two who so far have still the men's confidence. Capt. Black – lately detailed to 4th Battalion was a characterless snob – and full of the promise of a rotten M.O.

Today – the cause of these notes – Maj. Stack acted on 7 a.m. parade like a petulant child – and Maj. Lee followed his example at the 2 p.m. Pay Parade.

July 13

July 14

26.

The end of this month – by the leave list – I'll get my pass …. If my application for Transport home is not granted, I'll take my leave – and my pass will be to Killarney.

27.

Last night Bill Bliss come over from the 14th – from Warloy looking for me: saw him and had an hour's yarn – he as usual doing the 'yarn'.

28.

Silver's just thrown over Wilde's De Profundis, finish writing.

29. July 14

Yesterday bringing up particulars of personnel to date – from the Corps Order Book, I read some of the Divisional orders forwarded to the Ambulance after Bullecourt.

In orders 14 May 1917, the following has been received from the D.D.M.S., 1st Anzac –

The Director of Medical Services 5th Army, requests me to express to all ranks of the A.A.M.C. engaged in the recent operations, his great appreciation of the manner in which the evacuation was carried out by the stretcher bearers of Field Ambulances, and of the excellent condition in which the wounded reached the casualty clearance stations.

He realises that the devotion to duty shewn under very heavy shell fire could not have been surpassed and that in spite of the heavy stress of work, all wounded arrived at the Casualty Clearing Stations in a condition which testified to the thoroughness of the work at the Dressing Stations. (A.D.M.S. M 162/165)

In orders
Entry.14:
complimentary
, the Army Corps Commander wishes to convey to all ranks of the A.A.M.C. his keen appreciation of the excellence of the evacuation of the wounded during the recent operations. Not only was this

July 14

effected with the utmost care and expedition, but the courage & devotion to duty which caused all engaged in stretcher bearer work to disregard everything except the removal of their wounded comrades to the shelter & care of the Dressing Station, are beyond all praise.

That the barrage of fire through which the bearers carried the wounded, day and night, was of exceptional security, is shewn by the casualties in the Field Ambulance personnel engaged.

Sir William Birdwood is glad to learn, whilst the celerity of evacuation from the firing line to the Casualty Clearing Station could not have been excelled that the scrupulous attention given at the Dressing Station to the wounded noted at the same time, the admiration of the Administrative Consulting & Operative Staff of the Army. (1st Anzac R.O. 237)

In orders 20th May 1917

The following message has been received by G.O.C., 1st Aust. Division from G.O.C. 7th Imperial Division –

'As the 7th Division has just come out of the line, I wish to take the first opportunity of conveying thanks to stretcher bearers of 1st Austr. Division, on the great assistance they rendered to the wounded of the 2nd Gordons and 9th Divisions after the attack on Bullecourt on May 7th. (A.D.M.S. M.168/166)

Re the 2nd and 3rd taking of Hermies, Boursies and Dernecourt in orders
Entry.15:
Before departing on the 27th after his visit the Commander in Chief expressed his appreciation at the manner in which the Division has acquitted itself in the fighting to take Hermies, Boursies and Dernecourt, in the repulse of the counter attack on 15th April and in holding the Hindenburg Line and he furthermore asked me to convey his appreciation to the Troops.

From Divisional Commander pub. for general information.

July 15

30.

Almost the whole afternoon yarning in the Billet – Wilk – Mitch and self: after the crowd had gone to the cricket – Mitch started on Dogs – his strong subject. Then we went to Cats – to Country life and hermit living. By the side of a stream – work and a dog and sufficient ground for immediate needs: only shorts and sandals to wear, the sun to worship and life to live with Nature. Much of his country days had some dog tales: of the dog he gave away to the people living near him, his late night returns – and how one night he 'dominoed' him, accidentally, a stone between the eyes.

An afternoon spent yarning – in the way of the writing of one of Gene Stratton Porter's "Limber Lost" novels.

31.

Last night I finished reading Wilde's "De Profundis".

32.

Only once or twice Father ever mentioned to me my book extravagances - once when I asked him if he'd ever loved books, he told me yes: that he'd wanted deeply at one period a full set of all Stevenson writings. I hardly believed it, thought that if the desire had been great, its satisfaction would have been fulfilled. Now I must give up ideas and desires for collection of rare personal books – autographs and special press books. I have taken things till now too much as a matter of course, too confident of a future I've never really thought seriously about.

Two more years with Lindsay 'Apres' and filled in that time a full study of quantities and building survey, of planning principles, and of design of office management, and work supervising. After that? – money to be somehow made to start myself

July 15

and ambition to realise what I've till now idly fancied.

This I had once fully intended now I see its fantasy. Early edition of Wilde – and Metheun 1908 full edition: and a fairly compleat collection of the principle writers of the 1890's – some of them I've already got. Synge's first Cuala Press edition and the book of the "Riccardi Press". Lindsay's tale of Petronius and the 1883 edition in the works of Keats – besides a full set of books on Art generally and Architecture and Painting.

All my Military monie I'd ever spent fully on Books – even for the first pay had considered that the ultimate end of it. Dreaming on the trip from home – watching the water lap the side of the transport these books to be were half my imaginings.

33. July 16

A rainy and a dull day. The Col. and Eric back from the 3rd Echelon at Rouen and my application for transport Duty approved and forwarded with recommendation to A.D.M.S.

Mail today brought catalogues from "Bakers Great Bookshop" – catalogue of autographs and 1st editions.

About book catalogues – any catalogue very nearly – there's a real fascination: there's hardly anything so stimulating, and withal as tantalising.

If I have the time, when I get to Blighty I'll try and look up the particular bookshop – at Birmingham – in John Bright St.!

In one of the catalogues is priced Arnold Bennett's "Plain Man and his Wife" at 8/6 – the 1st edition that I paid
Entry.16:
for when it first came out.

34.
Entry.17:
Frank to Blighty tomorrow, so I'm installed in the O.R. – and to sleep there for the better guarding of secret papers and orders. One of these, relating to George Rex's visit of early this week is full of innocent charm - the troops to be disposed – with full Kits up along the Albert-Amiens road, as though resting from a route march, to cheer unaffectedly the car of the examining officer.

We came this terrible gutzer and had to march from here, packs up to the Amiens road.

"His most gracious majeste's deigning to so review his most unworthy Colonial Troops" – as King put it, "seems hardly appreciated" judging by his stupendous reception.

Shall his finish help materially in the finishing of this war?

35. July 17

The Food Controller of Pen 4 of Billet 63, Mitch's rationing was too drastic for his subjects so Algy and Buss led the opposition and Mitch with Biltman "came a gutzer!"

"Came a gutzer!" about the most impressive saying and Tag of the Division these three months past: it shares honors for first place with "on the grouter" or "at the Toot". In future "Ginger Mick" and "Sentimental Bloke", these will take high honoured places with the fullest native slang.

36.

Parcelling up tonight, for home "Interior Decoration" and "London Lamps". "Int. Dec." one of the greatest disappointments of my book buying.

37.
Entry.18:
This morning reported to A.D.M.S. at Baizieux and saw Col. Huxtable: he has promised to forward my application for 'Transport Duty' on to Division – "but" he says "they can't spare men fit for the line". Basil tells me he referred the forwarding this morning of a very full case – a man whose wife is almost an invalid, and who according to two Medical Certificates is incapable of looking after her two children.

A yarn with Basil afterwards in the farmhouse, he's often spoken of, filled half the morning: between us of course only one subject: books. From him I have a lot of the Everymans edition – the library that must satisfy me in the near future. I must continually get hold of Browne's "Religio Medici".

The afternoon horror: work of course – but barren wasteful stuff. This evening in Billets, behind Billet – yarning with Mitch on things worldly and spiritual.

Tonight I'll read "Les Miserables".

38.

Reading Thomas a Kempis last Sunday on the Brush road – this puzzled me – then struck me wonderfully –

"Many secretly seek themselves in what they do, and are not sensible of it."

As Nick said when I'd loaned him the "Imitation",

"Don't these things het a chap up?"

39.
Entry.20:
Yesterday I saw Col. Huxtable and he promised to forward my application today, it returns to the O.R. and he's appended note – he regrets his inability to approve …

40.

and another mail from home torpedoed. now two mails lost in the last few weeks, and probably all Father's last letters.

41. July 20

George not yet back from Blighty – and tonight I've finished the first volume of Les Miserables. The second's in his pack.

Today wrote to Times Book Club for Browne's Religio Medici and Pater's "The Renaissance" – the edition I bought in Sydney and read on the Transport and in Egypt. No mail today – and a dull tired day.

A good footie match – one that the Dad would have enjoyed - 'famous' Officers v. O.R., O.R. winning, a hard game.

42. July 20

Yesterday I'd a letter from Tom and looking up secret papers find he's billeted about Aveluy. It's about two years since I've seen him – and he's the chap I've often thought of as a partner when I'm a fledged Architect, he possesses what I'm lacking in – I possess what he needs: we would about give and take equally – but we've never discussed it. Apres? Before then though there'll be a terrible smash for us in Belgium. Will write to him tonight.

43.

Just back from the Chateau. In one of those high tall windowed rooms of the ground floor there are soft lights and there in the night are the sounds of a piano and of a man's rich voice.

Tonight I'll read Keat's Sonnets.

44.
Entry.21:
Word by telegram just through that Billy Aspinall has been "Killed in Action". 9.15 a.m.

45. 

Ready to turn in last night, Basil arrived with the promised "Country Doctor" of Balzac's. Till 11.15 we yarned – and it was a night's yarning such as is a rare experience. After he'd gone, I turned in in the dark and last night slept the sleep of a quiet mind.

46.

Today's a fine good day: Cricket between N.S.W. and the rest of Australia. Soccer against the 8th Field. Underwood has been reviewed for schooling at the Corps Officers training school at Aveluy, also Davis of C Section.

George back this morning from Blighty speaks of two Opera Companies in London, and two pieces seen by him, "Samson & Delilah" and "Carmen". To see "Tannhauser" or the "Tales of Hoffman", Killarney and the "beauty of the world through a mist of tears" – a Cathedral tourage – Lincoln – Lichfield and the Universities – or London – London and the Opera!

47.

Night: The day ends dully and a day of disappointment. 'How all occasions do inform against me' and "I am sick at heart', and really I've no reason – just the mood of melancholy and regret. Tonight I want high wonderful rooms, rich brocade hangings and woundrous fantastick etchings, Chopin's nocturnes and old wines, the company of Harry and of Dad … of the Dead.

48.
Entry.23:
It is not without reason that people speak collectively of the Priest, the lawyer and the Doctor, as "Men of the Black Robe". The first heals the wounds of the soul, the second those of the purse and the third those of the body. Balzac in The Country Doctor – reading it tonight.

49.

Today's been a full sun Aussy day, and as a result I've a "full sun" headache.

Basil sent down the Colonials Guide to London this evening.

Car to Aveluy and left with Pioneer in Albert letter addressed to Davies.

50. July 23

The good oil: Hell as its never been when we get to Belgium: we "pursuing troops" – and on breaking through almost inevitable.

The guns of the nearest front from here last night and now – 10 a.m. – bellowing their "fed-repriss".

57. July 23

11.30 – Movement – the oil – entrain at Edge Hill night of Thursday. Is it our turn or the 2nd to run the A.D.S.? We ran Byzantin le Petit in Jan., Feb., March so it seems its their turn though the rumour is that they'll run a C.R.S. up North.

Two more of Artilleries Details wounded – we to supply another pair – making 3 in two days.

58.

Reading this afternoon Balzac's "The Country Doctor", 'Genestas' tale of the episode of The Retreat from brought up again the nightmare of Flers.

"It was a pitiful sight, but it almost made me laugh", writes Balzac through the mouthpiece of Genestas: they were pitiful sights then, but the desire to laugh with us hardly came till three minutes had passed, and there's a similar winter again in front of us.

59. July 23

C Section back tonight from Doullens. Gave 'Country Doctor' to Eric – I didn't finish it – only to the end of the section part: Basil is waiting for the book, so was Eric, and I didn't feel any inclination to skip the other three parts: so with an appreciation that demands a second reading for the while I'll be satisfied, and the fact that the move is due is a preventing of the full reading Balzac demands.

Four years ago Angus were shewing a while in a separate window a splendid edition of Balzac in 50 volumes – or 40, limited to numbered 30 sets: they priced the set then at £25. Two years ago, before leaving, it was on final leave, the same set was priced £15 with a Bombay edition of Kipling, a large paper edition of Stevenson and a set of Meredith and Morris. The 23rd set of Morris at £11.11.0 and Balzac were two sets I've dreamed a hundred times of possessing, and at the time of leaving Australia of Balzac I'd only read "Honorine" and of Morris "The Life and Death of Jason" and his Early Poems and Prose romances. That 1000 copy set of Morris I'd particularly set my mind on – from the moment of the arrival of the first set of the volumes in Sydney till now. Yet absolute renunciation of Books is a renunciation of half my life, and perhaps. perhaps I may some day earn these two sets.

In the meantime 'Everymans Library' and ordinary editions.

60.
Entry.24:
Those long 'slender' casement windows of the chateau and the Musick room there windowed on each long side.

A Musick – Drawing – and Gallery room – for a rare small collection of only Australian pictures – water colour nocturnes of the Whistler school – finishing of line decoration – a small case of luxuriously bound books – the Poets and Philosophers – a room of rich colour – but of rich colours so restrained that no one colour may be singled as the obvious ground scheme – but of such colours that fit as the pieces of a wonderful brocade into their perfect placings. Deep chain brass candling lighting.

A room for Chopin's nocturnes, for reverie and old friendships: a room of self – and of quietness and wonder.

61. July 24

Today's mail – the second series of Molony Fellowship Books, and the July 19 Times Literary Supplement. In a list of Book Bargains the Times advertises "Red Letter Days" – being red letter days from the Diary of Samuel Pepys. 'Red Letter Day' seems rather a good phrase – for the day's fruitful of mail – letters from home and Catalogues and Books from Blighty.

The little Book of Georgian Verse – evidently the 3rd series – "Verses from the Grand Fleet" – Honey-Sight and seems the most promising as yet read – "In a Belgian Garden and other Poems".

By the Literary Supplement, Arnold Bennet has published another literary book – "Book & Persons" by the good publisher Chatto and Windus, Lord Dunsany, a volume of Plays and Maunsel's list added to: wrote to T.B.C. for Dunsany and Maunsel's 500 Poems.

July 24
Entry.25:
62.

Tonight read a deal of poetry and wrote 2½ pages of letter to Mother: wrote also to T.B.C. for two of Maunsel's newly listed books – Poems and something of Padraic Pearse's.

63.
Entry.26:
1.35 p.m. I'll know in ten minutes if its Tony or myself on leave to Blighty tomorrow.

3.30 Tomorrow DY, Leave to Blighty. The Dad dead less than six weeks, and leave to Blighty.

The Moving Finger writes, was one of Father's favourite pieces and the Omar, not his religion, contained not a little of his philosophy. Tears, mourning and worrying are useless, only one thing worries me – and till mail after the 15 comes through no worrying can help either Mother or myself. I will make the most of these next days – will spend them to an extent as I would have had I had my leave last December from the Base, and I know that spending it as I will will not be in any way other than he would have me spend it. Yet he is dead – and I hardly realise I, and leave to Blighty is a glimpse of Heaven after a year of Hell. My Pass to Killarney, Tony, Nick and Bill – next Friday, and while I'm away the Ambulance moves.
Entry.27: Tonight back to the only home I know – back to the Ambulance after 15 days away – after 11 days in England and Scotland.
Entry.28:
Petit Sec Bois

(Hazebruck) 

64.

Tonight letters – and some from home: one from the Dad, one from Mother and one from Betty: the date May 27, and Father was well then: this May 27th letter will be his last, the mail all June 12 has "gone down". One too from Mr. Toohey – that I'll send home to Mother.

Thank God for this journal, and for letters and books, and in books I'm strong now – one of Brooke's letters – of his selected verse – Materlinck's "Our Eternity", Artzebashef's "Breaking Point", A.C. Benson's "From a College Window", Gautier's "Mlle. de Maupin", poems "Earth of Cualann", one of Synge's plays, and again after 18 months away from him Pater's "The Renaissance".

Then from Charing Cross I sent to Bob Summerville some translations that I'll read later some time.

65. Aug. 10

In Hazebrouck yesterday morning – and this morning too – we saw the terror and tragedy of a civilian population of a great town under the fire of 16" shells.

We saw Basil and George at the offices of the A.D.M.S. and about 9 left there with directions to a tucker shop in the town square. Somewhere near, in the morning peace of a city, and the church bell tolling the death of a native, we heard only the sudden awful tearing smash of a shell, a few minutes and another, and another.

Old women and old men, young women and children and a scattering of soldiers of three nations. In great silent awful streams those women and children ran from the city, terror on their faces

Aug. 10
Entry.29:
and terrible terror in the torturing agony of the old women. If it hadn't been made so terrible by these trembling old women – rumour has it there are deaths from fright – that morning evacuation would have been only funny, and slightly pathetic, but these trembling women and their fear were high tragedy.

Last night – or early this morning they bombed a small village by us, that is the village the refugees made for from Hazebrouck.

66. August 11

One night coming back from Amiens in the train to Henencourt, three chaps half potty, in a carriage filled with Australians of a finished day's leave, were making a fair share of the row in the car: one suddenly lifted up his hand and demanded silence.

"Listen!"

In the full carriage on either side rise and fall the arguments and tales of the day – with the many full Australian adjectives. Solemnly then – "They're Anzacs, Bill, they're Australians!" Coming back from Boulogne in the leave train two evenings back, I was reminded of this, and listened to "the Anzacs". They argued and told their tales of a ten days leave that had in 90 cases of a hundred become a 12 days leave, and they summed up London, the British Isles and her people, and buildings, "I walked about a --- hour looking for the Strand, 'an I was in it all the while --". "-- dag of a place, ain't it!" "An' Westminster Abbey! – it wants a -- scrub, so do half the places.

"Did you see …"

(Next page but one!)

Aug. 11

67.

Tonight I wrote and posted a short letter to Mrs. le Friere – Aunt Louis! Last Sunday that I spent with her was a day such that only Brooke's Poem, 'Tenderly' "day that I have loved" could adequately express. A day of home after two years of Military Camp and Billets and Dugouts.

I have read today Brooke's "Letters from America" and they're fine: finer than any other travel letters I read, and to be read again, and perhaps again. he writes as I would - tonight with Yeats' plays I sent it home – a book for my special shelf to be.

Brooke, Masefield, Watson, Synge, Yeats and Swinburne – and novels of France, and Hardy, Meredith and McKenzie – plays of Shaw and Lord Dunsany – Wilde and Materlinck – these on my shelf of poets, novelists and dramatists.

I must read some of Hauptman and of Brieux. In London I saw two of his plays, "The Three Daughters of M. Dupont" and "Damaged Goods" – both well acted, well theatred, and well written plays – of more than usual impressions and full of only good. The art of Brieux is high and beyond the art of half the present day dramatists.

68.

At "London, London our Delight" you're our memories of half the days to come.

Toby back tonight.

Aug. 11
Entry.30:
"An' one thing I missed – the Waxworks!"

"Didn't you see them? – oh they're -- good!"

"An' those undergrounds! – dags aren't they?"

"An' Petticoat Lane of a Sunday morning! Christ she's a doer!"

So on and so on, a hundred talking at once, and the train going to a war that's getting a bloodier and a more terrible part of the lives of the world.

Aug. 12

69.

After three weeks – again the early morning run, the morning parade, and roll at 2 p.m. After dinner, in the lovely grass behind the thatched billet, under a full fruited pear tree reading till about 3 Alec Waugh's "The Loom of Youth".

At York, not being able to buy at the station stall the book I wanted in the Lotus Library, just as the train arrived I bought the day's "Spectator": it reviewed the book – so that the impression left was that it was of the "Sinister St." or "Hyssop" school. Now today I have half read it, remembering "The Hill" as a school yarn its not the best I've read, but the books to come from Waugh will be worth looking for.

Another novel I lately started was Artzebashef's "Breaking Point", it remains ¼ read, he writes brilliantly – his love of colour and his seeing of the beauties of things is fully written – but he is obsessed by the brutality of man – is struck by his physical beauty, too full of his weaknesses - I prefer his short tales to his long ones, his Nina, brutal and realistic in the

Aug. 12

extreme still remains a perfect piece of writing. Perhaps I'll finish "Breaking Point" – it is so very uneven, so full of horror and beauty that it facinates even when it repels.

70.

The day's been perfect – full sun and great white rolling banking clouds, it ends in heavy rain, and now with the "grey veils of the half light deepening" the rain clears coolly.

Tonight detailed for guard – third shift – 2 a.m. to 6, then 2 p.m. till 6 tomorrow afternoon.

71.

Posted tonight's letter, and 10 Francs to S.H. Bookshop in Museum St., London for Davidson's new Ballads and W. Watson's "Year of Shame". Two others of Watson's I'll get later "Odes and Other Poems", 3/6 and "The Hope of the World", 4/6, all 4 first editions.

Shop – Davis and Oriole. "Green Arras" by Housman there too at 7/6.

72. Aug. 12

The Cathedrals I was in during the twelve days in Blighty were, St. Pauls, The Abbey, Westminster Cathedral, St. Giles and York Minster. In York Minster I spent a full morning, and heard the most lovely service I've imagined possible. An Intercession in the Choir, only six others beside the Choir. I listened to that service as in a dream, no part of the world intruding. The exquisite voices of the surpliced and white ruffed boys, and seven men, the lovely harmony of voices, music more perfect than all the nocturnes of the world. The rich voice of the lesson reader, and the full charted responses, and towering around the high carved choir stalls, oak blackened by age, and rich in dim shadows, the magnificent powdered gold altar and the great west window

Aug. 12

rising behind it, of soft diamond glimmering glass fully massed over its great face with a hundred soft colour traceries, the music of voices and of a solemn organ, and the high vaulting losing itself overhead - that short lovely intercession service was the most lovely experience of twelve days.

Westminster Cathedral - to the generations that come down the years, Westminster Cathedral will be a great monument of today's art, it is magnificent, brilliant, and all of the cast, its incense and colour and wondour appeal to the intellect, yet spiritually it leaves a coldness and a feeling of overwhelming loss. I heard on the last Sunday night part of Evensong Benediction, and that part of Rome that had bewildered me and facinated me seemed lost with the responses, in the black domes above.

St. Pauls, the first Sunday we attended the 6.30 evening service. The regilding and decorating of the intercer is half finished and all the richness of renaissance magnificence is there. But the sermon irritated almost, a barren narrow affair of words, words, words, of narrowness and dullness - that sermon and a phamplet from Westminster Cath. on "Mixed Marriage" almost go hand in hand.

St. Pauls and Westminster are wonderful and full of magnificence, but York Minster is of all the beauties of God and The Christ. 

The Abbey, just Henry VIII's chapel. I'm forgetting the waxen effigy of Elizabeth, that and a painting of her at Holyrood in Mary Stuart's bedroom make an understanding of the Elizabethan age easier.
Entry.31:
70.

London Theatre – "Samson and Delilah" – the opera with Edna Thurston as Delilah, Sit Thomas Beecham's Company at Drury Lane – only passable. "Chin Chin Chin" – with Mick, and he to sleep heavily starts snoring – our seats in the centre of the Dress Circle. The scenery, staging, Dressing and Acting of this melting pot of opera, satire, melodrama, Russian Ballet and Pantomime, the most splendid of all elaborate mountings we've seen. It held me till the end – I could see it a hundred times and still enthuse over it, and chaps that see it merely dismiss it with "Jolly Good" while "Zig Zag" the most barren and dull of so-called Revues is enthused over.

Two plays by Brieux – "Damaged Goods" at St. Martins, and "The Three Daughters of M. Dupont" at the Ambassador. Two fine well acted plays at two jolly fine little Theatres.

"Romance", Doris Keene and a good well enjoyed play. "Mrs. Pomeroy's Reputation" by Vachell with Violet Vanborough lead, of the social comedy school, and the Mrs. Pomeroy of Violet Vanborough a living woman.

Susette - – "zee zhat mouth?", "zee zhat leg?" – but there wasn't the slightest need for her actually by word calling attention to their wondours.

And "Zig Zag" and Maid of the Mountains, for the latter six of us had a box – to the play Sappe insisted on calling "The Harlot of the Hills". It was a merry night out, with supper back at the hotel with three picked up stragglers from the Square.

"Ghosts" of Ibsen's was being played but I missed it.

Aug. 13

74.

Midday – Guard duty on A Section Billet from 2 till 6 this morning, the morning finish reading to the end of "Loom of Youth" and Campbell's "Earth of Cualann". Mail brings The Literary Supplement of Aug. 9 and Frank Richard's list mentions "An Attempt at Life" and "Loom of Youth" as the two promising novels – "Loom of Youth" – first edition exhausted before publication – second delayed by … and … by the fact that the Scotch printers chose the critical period to take a week's holiday.

Wrote to T.B.C. for Elroy Flecker's Poems – reduced to 3/6 also for Lollingdon Downs, Masefield's, last book of sonnets and verse.

75.

The day ends, the sky a soft pale dove colour, one thin pale slender line of green jade pointing a long finger across the sky. Planes the last hour have been 'going over' and the noise of the distant guns tiredly drags on and on …

76.
Entry.32:
A morning of gas Drill and a short lecture on the splendourness of our helmets compared with the ridiculous protection of the Boche …! – but if only one could believe it. 'Theirs' according to Fenton, 'can only be useful for from two to four hours – at the outside, consequently we are sending gas over continually till the German simply has to remove his helmet – and it. Splendid? how superbly humane we have all grown. One consolation only is that the blame is 4/5ths with the Boche.

In the afternoon a cross country run. Rowe ran in shorts only and shoes, what a sight if they all ran naked - so, if say twenty of them did, the rest in full heavy woollen wrappers - germans - as spectators. The lovely day, the sun and cloud, the wheat field by the

white road – the occasional tree by it and then rich shadows – and the narrow canal of Paris green ruled water. Instead, torn cut down underpants, odd sox, dirty grey or dull shifts, and handkerchief caps.

77.

Three of today's howlers …

Bib to a French Peasant, "Bon jour Manure, comment tel-el Kebir" – to his compleat wounderment! Mac – "Ah, well, you never can tell as Shakespeare said!", and Billy – "What's in a name '--- it' as Shakespeare would say. Today Shakespeare's strong.

78.
Entry.33:
I have been reading de Maupassant – three tales in a collection of translations by one M. Smythe, Dumpling, Two Friends and Moonlight.

Why is it that in English, de Maupassant always appears in cheap horrible editions and sold mainly by the derelict shops. Three tales of the book of several, and two of them gems.

Steenwerck-Nieppe

Dumpling and Moonlight – Moonlight an exquisite little cameo, as lovely as the best of France.

There is a full charm about the French writers that very rarely appears in any works of the English. Wilde nearest approaches to this atmosphere of all our men. Anatole France – Daudet – Gautier – de Maupassant and Flaubert, the Russian, Artzebashef, the other famous Russians I've not read sufficiently.

79.

Attached to 2nd C.C.S., the last entered interrupted by the warning to pack up.

80.

Wrote to Charing Cross Road to the people I bought "Form" at - about two works I bought there last Tuesday week – they've not turned up yet.

81.
Entry.34:
Thanks to the Pope the Mess had something new to discuss – or rather some new light on which to discuss our old subject - the 'Peace" offer became as the day goes more general and more possible of acceptance – it now includes compleat restoration of Belgium, Serbia and France – Alsace Lorraine to be French again and Italy to connected to her lost colonies - and still H.E. shells tear over us and the wounded arrive from the line.

82.

On night duty in the Dressing Room – 8 p.m. till 5 a.m. – all stretcher cases dressed by us – 4 and Sgt. Wylie – a good M.O. and decent dressing shack. Last night few cases, mostly N. Zealanders, this morning till C. exceptionally heavy bombardments. The day fine but rain about 8. 2 Duty.

82.
Entry.35:
Going on duty yesterday evening, in the Dressing room, met Sister Stuart of the 2nd - from her after much yarning hear that Val is married, is living in England and has a baby. By rumour I'd vaguely heard of her marriage, not of the baby.

Dear Val, why? and only last November or was it October, dear little girl I'm so sorry, we were so suited one with the other, not for the ultimate marriage but for passing love. Now if we were to meet again what would we say. Could Brooke's 'Second Best' come to your mind? It came to mine last night, and his sonnet –

Now that we've done our best & worst, and parted,

I would fill my mind with thoughts that will not rend.

Dear Val, and all that remains of a Springtime love

is your little note – the one you gave Jake for me, one evening after that day in Picardy.

With all your unemotional lines, Val, this ..

I asked Stuart for your address, but little girl, that last evening, when we quoted and were full of Rosetti and Swinburne, and made foolish love, we could not keep our love. Trembled and laughed and kissed – that will end our adventure lightly and keep romance about it.

83.
Entry.36:
Very heavy air raid between 9 and 10 last night, the search lights got well in to the raiding planes and the anti air craft shooting better than any I've seen. No casualties from the raid through the Dressing Room. The night lively in the extreme – a rich luminous black blue sky horribly bespangled by tiny far away glimmering stars. Early this morning a second raid and away towards our right flank.

84.

During the evening wrote to Mother, Elsie G., Elsie B., Joe's sister and Hazel, enclosed photographs in each letter.

85.

Breaking Point, Artzebashef – its full of madness and the obsession of suicide – full of the beauties of nature, and the most terrible of philosophies, such a and such people, such collective misery and entire lack of faith. I cannot conceive of as existing – even in Russia that most amasing and tragic of countries.

Chapters magnificent and horribly sordid and follow relentlessly and terribly.

86.
Entry.37:
Tonight I am restless and my mind won't fix itself, since tea I've read le Gallienne's Worshipper of the Image – a rotten affected fantasy – a few pages of Mdle. de Maupin, of Les Miserables and an essay of Pater's 'Botticelli'. Its still early in the evening, but late - the raid till now has been less severe and the night is comparatively quiet. I am still undecided whether to keep for Apres "Breaking Point", though morbid and deadly the book contains some wounderful passages, and its certainly worth its book room. No mail.

This morning work kept us going solidly from 4 a.m. till 9 – the five tables, and till 11 yesterday night the raid kept us at 'Breaking Point' – it was solid in the extreme, and hellishly unnatural – the search lights picked up three of the planes well and the air craft guns' fire brought one down. There must be a hundred machine gun positions about here, for directly a plane appeared leprously on the thin ray of the search light all the air sang with their firing, the machine guns, the heavy crump of the bombs, and the firing of the anti A.C. guns and then shells exploding, the far drum fire from the line, filled the night hideously. We had no cases through. Tonight's raid, the night's not over yet, but the planes that have so far been over avoided the lights. Distantly bombs are crumping.

87. Aug. 19

For the quiet loveliness of our old room, of books and Poetry, of etchings and water-colours, Nocturnes, of folios of drawings and soft lighting, for fantastick reverie and the facination of loosed imaginings.

Gothick - and I'll carve my panels, that door frieze from Amiens Cathedral will inspire a mantle, or the over door design of the Chapter House of York Minster, black in Flemish oak, and a few Riccardi volumes or leather books .. No, many books of the Poets, Philosophers and Essayists, then the room will be classical – beautiful in simple lines and lovely decoration, colourings. The study the Jacobean styles and Arts.

88. Aug. 21

a.m. Last night's raid the quietest yet, one plane passed over in towards Hazebruck probably – another dropped his bombs somewhere towards our left, the searchlight failed to pick either plane up.

Bombardment early this morning slightly heavy, cases during the night few – the few being of rather a light nature, those few were the only ones left of several parties.

89.

Yesterday brought to the staff of the 2nd C.C.S. an Australian mail, of June, the mail reported sunk.

90.

The last three mornings a train has come up for clearing the station, each day at 4 we've started dressings and gone steadily till 8, then a big stunt in the air, and tonight by the report, some wounded 18-20 through, our Division is relieving them. As one of the Inf. chaps in the train from Boulogne said, "Too --- right!, we'll be in it solid son – to take a little village by name of Lille."

91. Aug. 21

Waking suddenly I dreamed early this morning, a stretcher case and ten walkers woke me up. In the dream I'd hurriedly risen, put on my gown, and started uncovering the face of the stretcher case, the last bandage revealed as it lifted a skeleton face with tattered fragments of flesh and smeared with blood.

92.

p.m. Algy and Tommy up from Petit Sec. Bois with a bag of mail, one from Father, June 3, and he writes of 25 years of marriage on the 15th, of it seeming half that time, one from Mother dated June 3, and she speaks again of June 15, one from Geoff, of Football with school and a mention of our mother, who takes a 'hell of a while in getting to the point', one from Mat. of Goulburn and coming to Queen St. - June 15.

93.
Entry.38:
And two Bulletins – the first for ages - there's a full home flavour round the Bulletin, it's the most defined Australian we know. M. Forest scarce in a poem of his "Fans" – it's delicate and suggestive, it might almost be a piece of Middleton's or Wilde's - the Red Page reviews "The Immortal Dorian" well – extract from Diaries of the A.I.F. abroad.

From the 'Book shop' no sign yet of 4 numbers of 'Today', Dunsany's 'Plays of Gods and Men' and one of The Lotus Library, ordered for forwarding Aug. 15.

94.

Tonight special orders re lighting out – there's suspense in the air and the raid wasted on!

This morning in bed finished Stephen Phillips' "New Inferno". It's good – strange I'd expected something different.
Entry.39:
Aug. 22

95.

Two 4th D.A.C. chaps just through dressing room – one to theatre then to A.B. – both for operations immediate – if they live till they're under the anesthetic. One was opening a Boche new cap. This case was the most terrible – abdomen and chest ripped badly. The other, his R. arm shattered terribly and small perforations through his chest, his R. leg torn all down. Both their faces torn bloodily.

Even the few days I've been here, a whole row has been added to the cemetary – to this close forest of plain crosses.

96.
Entry.40:
Tonight an inferno of war – machine guns innumerable against bombing planes, and the noise of the Anti-air craft guns, bombs dropped seemingly between here and Steenwerk near Nieppe.

At 2.30 this morning gas over - which reached down to here.

Aug. 22
Entry.41:
97.

After tea – to near the Steenwerk village with Robbins, there against the stacked drying wheat, in the shade from the rich willows by the arsenic leaf covered canal, yarning five minutes, musing an hour.

The quietness of these wheat fields – the colour of the stubble and the sun on the stacks – and the lines of willows by canal, make the sound of the guns, and the presence of baloons and planes in the skies ironical in the extreme.

The yellow of the wheat, and the green of the trees, there's the ground work colour scheme of my room at home.

Tonight reading and by heart a deal of it, Brooke's "The Great Lover".

Today hot – and no mail.

98. a.m. Aug. 23

One of day dreams seeing Brooke's Poems started yarning of verse, lent him the for the day.
Entry.43:
p.m.

99.

After Brooke –

These I do love,

Absurd blown sky and swimming clouds,

High hazy stars – 8 deep black vaults of night.

Add Gothick carvings, 8 shadow traversed roof,

Cold gleaming brasses, and time riched tapestries,

Songs and all sonnets of Elizabethean days,

Low Hyssop laden nocturnes, and

Old slim green bronze of fantastick gods,

Long golden beaches, and lazy curling surf,

The sun on young brown bodies, and

The shade of forests, and rolling growing trees,

And songs of hidden water,

But most of all,

Old memories of home.

100. August 25

Paid today – and drew 40 F. Yesterday and this morning the usual train rush for dressings. No mail up with Frizzle, and no word of the Unit's moving.

Yesterday arrived Watson's Year of Shame and Davidson's New Ballad. Davidson is worth cultivating, he's universal but with a genuine – not affectedly so.

Throat still bad after two days and a headache forbids long reading.

Yesterday wrote to all at home, and to Commonwealth Bank – and made out cheque of £5 to Robbins.

101. August 26

Rupert Brooke, William Watson,, Stephen Phillips and John Davidson and Pater's Renaissance and Gautier's Mdlle. de Maupin – yet today I dreamt of the reading of Swinburne, and its over 9 months since I first read his Poems and Ballads. Tonight I'll write to Bakers for his "A Song of Italy" – the 1st edition and only 6/6.

I'll use the envelope I have had since Henencourt addressed to him: that was to order a book of Symons.
Entry.44:
102. 9 p.m.

Tonight raining and a heavy sky, which will mean all the mud misery of Flers in the line, a slough of despond for the bearers in the evacuation of the wounded, and all the misery of the world for the chaps on the stretchers. They'll be carrying four to a stretcher – if the aid posts can't hold the cases for the night there'll be a rain sodden silent party slowly plodding through the slush of mud – deep to their calves, and full of a hundred treacherous holes. There'll be only instinct to guide them, the night's black as hell. Yet somehow or other the instinct rarely fails them – they'll be lost for an hour, and all the while firmly assuring the chap they're carrying they know exactly where they are, and then suddenly they'll arrive at the relay post, with a relief in their hearts that's a prayer of praise.

It's raining evenly and hardly, on the iron roof of the dressing Room. Along its whole length there's the insistent beat of heavy rain, and the day's been moderately fine, there'll have been the usual line shelling.

Thank God for the infinite pity of the chaps in the line, not for their pity though as for their sympathy – their glaring lies of comfort to the chap knocked. In the spoken aside, "Poor Bastard!", there's more feeling than in the most perfect poem. War conditions bring out the most perfect, and the most revolting passions.

Aug. 26
Entry.45:
103.

Last night, without the slightest warning, two quick following bombs were dropped alongside the C.C.S. Two Boche bombs from a plane that was over ours.

104. August 27, a.m.

Through the night very few through. Rain held solidly till 11 – cleared then returned. Train this morning, but very few dressings. The chap that came in yesterday morning – with his face blown off – not on the tables. No one seems to know anything of him.

105. p.m.

Tonight a mail up from Billets, from Mother, Geoff and Grandma, two from Mat. and a couple of others.

From Mother – June 24, and from Geoff – the 17th.

On June 15, the day of 25 years marriage, the civil ambulance brought back to Mother, Father dead.

Geoff seems to have kept up well, and unknown people's tributes seem to have brought an element of comfort.

Geoff has 'given up all idea of enlisting now'.

Mr. Parrish is to manage Father's affairs.

Geoff with a full heart writes, - For heaven's sake don't give up. Dear Dad. I'm looking to you not to give way, but to 'carry on'. Conditions here compel to cold carrying on, without revealing the heart for an instant. To think is to die.

106.

A rainy day, and it's raining now – nearly midnight. Back at the Unit a Dinner on the occasion of the third Anniversary of the Unit's life. Of the original Bearers how many? Nearly all the original left are those of the Nursing Section.
Entry.46:
107.

Off duty this morning – to a tent rakishly half lying on the sodden ground, with her skirts most carelessly drawn away from half our gear, half the guys broken, and a gale blowing: still we're back in her again and vaguely wondering how long she'll last.

108. p.m.

Tonight parcelled up Watson's "Year of Shame" & Davidson's "New Ballad", & addressed them to Mrs. le Freire, also wrote to her. Wrote too to Bakers of Birmingham for Swinburne's "A Song of Italy".

Tonight is a clear star hung moonlit night, clear to perfection for the Boche, and us.

In yesterday's Times there's an account of the several hospitals, French & English, the Boche has lately shelled and Bombed, they don't mention the shelling out of the 3rd C.C.S. from half way between Poperinghe & Vlamertinghe or the 44th British alongside there, or the bomb dropped here a few weeks back, or the bombs dropped on our own Clearing Station at Buire last year, or the three days shelling out of the M.D.S. at Vieux during the Bullecourt stunt.

109.

Few days back lent Basil "Breaking Point", tonight here yarning, it was good discussing the points of the book and its unevenness.

110. August 29, p.m.

Rain again, and even here where duckboards have been a year, the place is miserable. A cloudy night, with a bright moon behind. No mail or word up from Unit.
Entry.47:
111.

Tonight nothing to write of, and only a desire to write. I've de Maupin, Brookes, and a phamphlet by the Catholic Truth Society – I bought it with others one day in Westminster Cathedral, on the Supression of the English Monastries: a good subject and an interesting one. History I'm slack in. At Fort St. I turned it down in some way that now I'd tremble to try – and only look in on at the Grammar, because I couldn't get out of it. There Charlie's sauve Catalogical Questions were our bugbear, and Butch usually backed me up. And Charlie had a great way with too – it's to him I continually owe a deal of my appreciation of Browning, and the decent essay. At Fort St. Cuthbert did all in his power to everlastingly call my curse down on anything and everything literary. In English he'd put all blackness in my mind, by asking for interpretation of Tennyson's "Lancelot & Elaine" – only when he was sure I couldn't interpret. All the smugness of misunderstood loveliness was his.

English at the Grammar was always good: there if the lesson before had passed well Charlie'd be in a mellow mood and he'd read to us if he'd the slightest chance, and the recollections of "The Pied Piper", "John Gilpin" and "The Ancient Mariner".

James Stephens somewhere says that 'the average man as readily bends to beauty as the flower to the wind'. Com. 1, certainly bent willingly to Charlie's readings

Aug. 29
Entry.48:
and without doubt enjoyed quite as much as the reader these three pieces.

112.

Finished the reading of The Suppression of the Eng. Monastries by William Collett.

I'll to History – as a change from Books and the Arts, say the periods of Henry VIII and principally of Elizabeth, the Virgin Queen.

113.

Mother, reading son's letter, "Will's letters always send me to the dictionary!"

Second ditto, "That's nothing! Frank's always send me to the Bank!"

114. August 30

Still occasional rain, and a little sun: now the sky heavily overcast, a yellow feverous flicker over the horizon with the slow dully booming guns. Last night only 5 cases through, and they mud soaked and cold. Two of our chaps spoke of their being relieved by the Manchesters, & they going to trenches blown in and heavy rain soaked. They speak of a place of mud approaching to Flers, but Flers will never be surpassed. One of the chaps, a Tommy, and he with a bullet through his face too: almost obviously a S.I. – first it was his own rifle that was fired, then a second he'd picked up to load! We marked him accidental, but he'll be S.I. at the Base. There's no incentive in his mind, and no hope, he's the result of the Army's discipline, and he was the type they shoot for "cowardice". They shoot for cowardice, and award for heroism, and everyone

Aug. 30

has come to know the vague invisible dividing line.

115.

Flicker and Masefield overdue, and the books from the Book Shop - tonight arrived the "Collected Works of Padraic Pearse" and they promise well.

116. 

J's to parade tomorrow to the A.D.M.S. re transfer to A.F.C. application and Harry Coffey left unit yesterday for home: his application went through.

117.

Tonight I have read again of Browning, "The Statue & the Bust", and "The Bishop orders his Tomb", both lovely and perfect poems, or an attempt at Romance, one, and a creation of brilliant and tragic liveliness the other. The book from some friend of one of the Day Dressers, the owner a Methodist student who aspires towards beauty. My Browning I sent home last Nov. leaving the 2nd A.G.H.

118.
Entry.49:
Tonight I have been reading again from the book of 'works' of Pearse. Now I've just finished "The Singer". Last night I finished the verse at the end of the book and then this morning a couple of the Tales. But The Singer is splendid. All I know of Pearse is all the Book Shop man of Charing Cross had to tell me - he was a "remarkable man, one of the Rebels, and he was shot with Casement", now in the light of this book, & especially after the reading of "The Singer", there comes the desire to know more of the man, and certainly this new Irish Movement & all its Questions should repay well a little following. The 1890's I know pretty well, now I think I'll

Aug. 31

follow the Irish Movement. Maunsels publish a lot on this. "The Irish Literary Renaissance" I fancy, and it should prove by its title the guide Holbrook Jackson's 1890's did. The Oxford Movement will wait: Synge, Yeats and The Irish Theatre now appeal far more, and the reading of these works offers more intimate facination. But Pearse I must know somewhat of.

119.

Every light's screened here as on the darkest night, and blankets doubled cover the windows and doors, outside its clear and light with a bright moon, and a sky of few clouds. Its near 11 oclock, our planes have passed over, they've not yet come back. The Boche has kept low - till now. Again after nearly a week of quietness owing to the damnable bosche the guns are opening out. This evening in Steenwerck there were plenty of the 8th, and some of the 6th, our "oil" is that we're for Ypres early next week. "To take Little" still runs well, but there seems no interest attached to our future doings. Above all other philosophies ours is now, 'Come make the most of what ye yet may spend'.

Wrote tonight to Mother, and to Charing Cross, re those books I bought there at the beginning of the month - first number of "To-Day" & the new plays of Lord Dunsany.

August's reading list quite approaches to one of the old first diaries lists – September will slacken – will be running then an A.D.S. or a M.D.S. and war will be in us again.

120.

Heard by the tent – N.Z.s playing Two up up, "Emus & Kangaroos stick out all over his face!!!"

September

120.
Entry.50:
This morning to Steenwerck – there a haircut and a walk round: back to C.C.S. and over to Zoi for coffee. There spent an hour designing in sketches of marvellous ballets, & wonderful stagings. "A Ballet of the Arts" – Musick, Painting, Sculpture, Architecture and Literature. 'A Ballet of the Period', Cretean, Egyptian, Truscan, Roman, Byzantine, Romanesque, the Renaissance and the Modern: "A Ballet of the Schools" – Painting, and 'Ballet of Byzanteum' & a Medieval Ballet.

Two stage settings I lean towards – black tapestry heavy folded and a deep white frieze heavily overlaid by a Jacobean of orange scarlet and gleaming gold – a floor of night sky blue – and a few square same colour pedestals supporting some colour stained antique reproductions. The Ballet ? This for a setting, another, entirely of black, the ballet a ballet of the nude, & a pointed doorway at back gold-embroidered 'round, lighting round system of dull glowing – on wrought iron - harp and pointed holders.

121.

Tonight Jim back for parading to A.D.M.S. and he successful - bring back note from Nick enclosing page of letter for Molony of the details of the Dad's death.

122.

Next week the two Divisions to go in and Ypres the front - it's rumoured the other three Divisions go down to the Somme!!!

123.

At the Unit things seethe. Hunt is again prize giving for Kindergarten prettiness, for the four nicest looking in the Section – clean brasses and Kiwi prettiness, marks deducted for long hair, for teams in uniform and a thousand minute faults that are insult to refer to …
Entry.51:
124.

A quiet night, so it was sleep from midnight till 5, the night was cloudy but light, no planes over, either Bosche or our own. This morning rain has it again, and a dull even sky promises no clearing up. Writing in the Church Army Hut, to get away for a while from the conversation of Buckholz – liquor extras and edibles – or his spreading of the news that we're going up the line early next week: seeing that the furthest he'll get will be the M.D.S. or at the farthest the A.D.S. that jars rather. When I joined up the Ambulance, Syd. told me that all that happened to the bearer became the adventures of the 'sisters' and our dangers nought to theirs. And now God help me I'm one of the "sisters". If it wasn't for the Mater I'd certainly get back to the Bearers: infinitely they're the better company and the more manly.

Last night two of the sixth bearers in the dressing Room to fix over windows and doors – stayed by Buckholz, spent an hour yarning: for a while I was tempted to join in, but when Buckholz turned the conversation and the of a knock at some time or other came up, and he cites his 3 yrs. service – in the Nursing Sect. and a big whack in England, I stayed where I was. To give the his due, I suppose he'd shape as well as another at bearing, but his present attitude towards himself and the wounded is intolerable. He is the quintessence of affectation – and to hang his affectation on he has nothing, and the idea of he and Morris criticising any of the bearers – as they do – I must see only the ironical side and smile, if I can.

Sept. 2

125.

There's a phonograph on the corner and rain like miniature machine gun fire over the roof. I'll have concert on my own.

(1) William Tell, Rossini

"Pipes of Pan", Arcadian

'My Hero', Chocolate Soldier

(2) William Tell

The Cygne, Saint Saens

The Gaby Glide, Hirsch

Cavalleria Rusticana

So, then came in one 'Anzac' and Banjo solos were called for - they're playing them now.

Pipes of Pan – the Bonzer old Arcadian, and the Dances in the second act, the chap who was drowned at Manly. The first time I saw "The Arcadians" the day after the results of the Junior 1910 came out – seven years ago to the month.

The Gaby Glide started me thinking, what vision of the Gaby herself and those Gaby dances, will the hearing of today's musick call up to those generations down the years. Will anything of Gaby and all her soft exquisite wonder and her posings that are poems rise in soft before them? Probably they'll only see a richer caricaturing prototype of their favourite Tivoli Girl and sneer accordingly. Will any have - we've seen Gaby - and only a hundred years can produce such a marvel. She'll die, and the blind worms will possess her, that exquisite body of hers will dissolve, and her soft dresses mould in the corners of old clothes shops, & ultimately become the disdain of the staid suburbanite.

Poor Gaby and poor us. Now to Zoi's for coffee and her rare philosophy.

Sept. 2

126.

p.m. Back at the tent after writing this morning some letters, amongst them one from Jessie G. She writes of Mother's wondering how to do up papers to me as the Dad did. That has been the most tangible word to me here – the Dad's writing or the Bulletin & the Times changing suddenly to Geoff. Dear little Mother!

127.

Nearing midnight. The raid, the first for some time is all about us – the night's clear & already by the crumps some big bombs have been dropped.

Four letters finished, one of three pages to Lindsay – he worked me into the A.I.F., there's a chance he may get me back. One to Mother – two cards only and the same to Billy, and an answer to Jessie's letter of this morning.

Five minutes ago finished packing gear – pack and rolling blanket, and washing two hankies - word is tomorrow we rejoin unit before moving up.

Today's been a long day. Writing after breakfast, some letters arrived, over to Zoi's for coffee, and then for a long walk through three villages. Those damnable machines in the air with their terrible loads, and me thinking of home. Oh !

128.
Entry.52:
Till 6 this morning the Bosche planes were over here and all about the sector. Rumour has it that three of our Art. officers were killed at Bailleul. Some heavy bombs were dropped & some fairly close to the C.C.S. Today's the promise of a glorious day, sun, milk blue sky and a few vague heaping clouds. There'll be a raiding today. Nothings known of our relief. Today for the sun while he lasts.

Sep. 3

129.

Midday Mess A – being mentioned, the subject of individual phisique was brought up, and the Unit's Apollos were discussed. It became heated: A – strongly favoured by Arthur – his choice judged bad by most of us, tho' not all. Almost of the whole crowd there's only one A.L. ---, perhaps B-- and N--.

Frank Hungerford and Jake & Walker of the old 2nd, three almost perfect types, Jake with all the individual beauty of Australia, full of grace and litheness, Frank wonderfully proportioned, full limbed and a perfect torso, Walker of fine moving and clean rich bodied flesh. From the old second of Egypt a splendid crowd could be assembled, Frank and Jake are two to remember.

130. Sept. 3

The Day's been perfect, again spent the day roaming, reading and lazing. Aerial activity has been brisk, and tonight there's an unbooked stunt. It's the baloon that flew over the station and almost us they're after - regularly they fire with their H.E. shrapnell, so they're looking to bombs.

Only mail up, Times Literary Supplement of Aug. 30. Wrote re last order of 13th and added Frankau's & Drinkwater's latest.

131. 9.45 p.m.

I've been reading a book I found in the St. George Hut – one of George Birmingham's, "The Bad Times". At Wimereux after the Easter Rising I read Brooke's "The Irish Question" – tried to understand the rising from that, but failed. Even now the Fenian I know

only as a name. Yet the Irish Question beckons me and it seems to offer me more interest and inclusion than the Question of my own country, and Father never seemed to feel for Ireland, and Grandfather I never knew. All my people, interests and loves are of Australia, yet to Ireland I feel an owed allegiance, and all the while I've the feeling of the uselessness of it all, the waste of enthusiasm and the dullness of her future. What is her future to be, she seems a country of wounderful beauty and dull brutality, hardly brutality, more of dull awful deadness.

I wish there was someone here to talk to without prejudice. I've just tried it with Norm, but he holds the Popish bogey as the whole heart of the differences.

I've read again the Dad's first letter addressed to the Amb. and tried to read something more than is written into it. Who was that great grandfather General who Commanded an Irish brigade against England, and when was it.

It's midnight and the Bosch planes are raiding again.

132.
Entry.53:
Slept from midnight till 7, train left at 9 but very few cases for Dressings. The Bosch over twice but the second raid passed while I was asleep. Today again is fine, there'll be some more solid peppering at the baloons.

Sleeping in that S cover Bell tent – by the sun an absolute oven and with H.E. shrapnell

Sep. 4

bursting at spasms above – high certainally – but the pieces & the case has to come down – makes the day's rest impossible. The few casualties of the last week have made nights easy for us, and the sleeping in the hut has suffered, but these conditions come pretty hard on those sisters who are working here. They've got a dug-out certainly but it's more of a funk hole for bomb attacks, they sleep in an ordinary marquee. Last night during the first part of the raid, Stuart was in the D.R. – she's night duty in A.1 and A.2, she was inclined to be a trifle 'windy' but our company and our laughing at her put her right. Even so it's a big strain for them, and then being here for any considerable time is asking too much of them and when all's said and done, apart from the men's influence of their presence – not a small matter when a man who is broken and dying is concerned – they are of no more benefit to the wounded than the men, the women's place is farther back, at a G.H. they carry the greater burden of the work, but here the work is for men.

133. Evening

At Zoi's after tea finished reading "The Bad Times". The book published in 1908. Rafferty is speaking, the scene is his ruined cottage on Ilaun an Anama - the Island of Souls – which the English making maps of their Irish possessions marked down as the Island of Soles.

"And we did it!" said Rafferty. "We, a handful of men, frightened them with all their soldiers and their ships of war. And who were we? The Church was against us, the gentry hated us. Tho' most of the people

cared nothing for us, yet we frightened the English. But, sure, we failed."

And again last Easter twelve months they failed again, failed with the same success. And England said the influence of Germany was at the heart of the tragedy. I don't believe it, or if the Bosch influence was anywhere, it was used as a means to an end. The very essence of Irish character is as different to that of the Bosch as England and Australia. I'll read Birmingham again, I thought all the readable novelists, I didn't.

134.

"Like many another before him, and many since his time, Father Staunton became the victor of the fascination of utter sly denial. Thomas a'Kempis set Jesus of Nazareth before the eyes of men as no one else ever did. The man who has once felt the tender pathos of the stresses that breathe out the words of the "Invitation" can never reckon on escaping from the slavery of Jesus. He may lose sight for a while of the Master of whom his soul is enamoured, he may put out of his mind the words so that they do not haunt or trouble him, but at unexpected moments, at inconvenient times, just when he desires them least, the words will come back to him. The figure of the Master will be before him, the passionate pleading of the sorrowful eyes will compel him." The Bad Times, G. Birmingham.

135.

Again tonight we come up against the M.P. Tommies of the 8th Division – permanents. Zoi and Ange were serving to us coffee – N.Zs and our own chaps, the time 8.15. And they brought up the tyrannous law of no coffee or Beer after 8, they sell nothing 

Sept. 4

but Eggs, Salad and Coffee to the Frogs and their parlour is invariably full – at all hours. And these 'bloody' M.P.s threaten to enforce the keeping by these two girls of the serving hours of only 12-2, and 6-8, between other hours they are to keep closed house. They provide us with clean decent tucker that we can get nowhere else and they keep their charges lower than anywhere else in the Somme, added to that they're open to howling raids and regular shell fire.

And the English bring this unfair and uncaring piece of beastliness into their orders.

136.

Today writing saw an Infantry man addressed envelope - Away.

137.
Entry.54:
Early this morning I dreamed I was home again, and the dream is still in my mind. Home in the dream was more like Burwood than Muston, Mother and Grandma were sitting by the front of the house, I felt myself running across the lawn & I was in Grandma's arms and Mother was running away, when I caught her she seemed to not know me.

The dream remains and the dull terror of it.

138.

Early morning – the prettiest piece of aerial performing we've seen for a long while. The Bosch are in low, but above one of our own planes. Then the diving, rising, volplaning and climbing were perfect. The Bosch drive our man almost to earth and through a most intense barrage gets here. Again an hour ago the performance

Sept. 5

repeated – though the position reversed. He's been full of bluff and gameness today, which is strange after all his late previous care, and he flew lower last night in his raiding, which all points to a coming movement on our part he's not looking forward to, the oil still is we are going in before Sunday.

139.

Met at Zoi's – after Coffee with Robby, a N.Z. and we yarned an hour on the Architecture and the wonders of the places we've seen.

The day's lovely – sunny & warm, more of a perfect Spring Day than one of Autumn.

140. 9 p.m.

Tonight a concert by the 4 D.A.C. in one of the cleared out ward shacks. Full of Ragtime, and good stuff too. One gave to me an entirely new interpretation of the 'Musick'. You could translate none of the words from the Musick, the voice merely became a weird accompanying to the piano. Buck damns to the lowest hell all Ragtime, by an Italian name the rose would smell sweeter. The damning led to an argument – and I as the champion of Ragtime - usually I mistrust it - I contended it the musical expression of the age – a statement I'd have been hard put to explain, and he damned the age, as "decadent, preposterous and entirely void of art and Artistry. And to explain his understanding of that terrible word 'Art', he asked "what Artists have we – what Artists?" When I took the wind from his sails by 

cataloguing names – and cataloguing them under the headings of Literature, Painting, Sculpture and Architecture, using as arts. Rodin and the English portraitists and Impressionists, he withdrew with majestic superiority.

As for literature, the present age is certainly the most productive of the years. Poets, minor and otherwise abound as the supply of ball from the machine guns, and such a bewildering number of novelists and essayists have reached such a standard of style and manner, that it would seem every second reader wrote to be read, and widely too.

141.

Seeing that this is a 'Diary', the raid last night of no excitement. I slept through it but lazily heard the machine guns in the air firing down the road alongside the station, some apparently went through some of our lines of marquees but beyond narrow escape there was no gain or harm done. About the time of the splendid 8 p.m., he dropped from a great height five bombs by the but did no damage.

It is significant that he neither shells nor bombs Steenwerck, and the church square would make a most paying – there are so many lorries there, and two full workshops. There's one explanation only, the place is filled with well working spies, who evidently justify their immunity from shell fire.

By the French paper this morning heard that Riga was seriously menaced, tonight hear she's already fallen.

Sept. 5

Quite obviously the Bosch fears on this front – if the weather continues fine he'll have reason. The road for some which last night was under the traffic of guns, and again tonight, at intervals lately too though some of the N.Z. guns have come down, a far greater number have gone up. Then again the air has filled for the full share of straffing, and tonight's raid has started.

Three submarines reported "by one who knows in a high place" sunk by Boulogne harbour. The second day bringing no mail or paper. Boulogne port closed. By the T.L.S. of Aug. 30, Waugh's "Loom of Youth" in its 4th edition. If Toby still has it 'whole' will send it home to Geoff.

Sept. 5
Entry.55:
142.

Reading tonight – and its jolly interesting – a phamplet I bought in Westminster Cathedral, "The Benedictines", writing of the grandeur and "splendid ritual of the church – The existence of God is, in the mind of the Benedictines' work, an opportunity for giving to Him the very best. To aim at perfection in solemn ceremonial, in Art, in musick and in architecture is deemed a duty which man owes to God, and for him alone exists all that is generous and beautiful in creation."

143. Sept. 6

Early about 4 a.m. heavy rain, then a solid carnage of fire from our guns that lasted a good hour. Quietness a while, and then heavy artillery fire again and is still lasting well at 10 a.m.
