Wrote two pages of letter to Mother, & will keep one to post. Dreamt again badly, of Mother in Edinburgh, and the mother of last night's dream.

Sept. 6

144.

An anti aircraft dud shell through the mortuary this morning, the dead had just been buried. Lying here in the tent – regularly in the winds at 10 oclock we hear the low monotonous intoning of the burial service and the following lights out. Follows the salute by the two bearers, the bugle, and perhaps by a rare mourner, and the marketed body is buried closely to those of yesterday and the long row of the dead surely fill the whole long field. Mark each dead exit of his country a plain bare wooden cross with its three aluminium strip of his name, his unit and his country.

And to the morning of those "Rich Dead" comes to the mind with all their beauty Brooke's lovely sonnets, Blow bugle Blow and "If I should die".

What is their ultimate place in creation: I think they will rest well, and they'll know goodly company, and their spirits well joining to the only Heaven they've known, Australia.

145.

A wonderful green black 'inverted bowl', and soft mist all round the horizon: the light clear, and the green of the trees and grass very beautiful, thunder rushing over the skies like heavy manacle chain dragged over great space, and faint flickering forked fantastick lightning, the rain, and a discharge of great drops. Now the skies of thin menacing clouds, and the air crisp & cool.

146.

Met tonight here an old pal of Jonas's, and the whole of the school of his followers are alive again in memory. Pater, the Russian pagan, who believed in nothing, George Martin the once close bosom pal of Frank Hungerford then of McDougal, and Bartlett.

Sept. 6

George and Frank the greatest of pals in Egypt, and a well matched pair – clean living & direct chaps. Then in France Frank was dropped for Mac, and their palship was a very real thing till Mac was killed at Flers, now the last I heard of George was from Clarrie, who saw him in B Details. George is for the Methodist Ministry, Mac was "a wanderer in the middle mists". Bartlett was a – is – a C. of E. Minister, inarticulate in an argument, and Jonas the leader of us all – a convert to Rome, and full of the wondour and learning of the church. Tall. ascetic, full of enthusiasm that lit his eyes and filled him with animation, with a luminous ivory, always ready and full of an interested tolerance as Mac for a Max Beerbohm portrait.

147. Sept. 6

The only 'oil' available on the heavy hours bombardment early this morning, no cases from the force of the bombardment through the Dressing Room, the 'oil' came from a chap down from Armentieres, from him the bombardment was above Armentieres, we had sent over some new gas – gas that burns the helmet of the Bosch through and liquid fire, the Bosch infuriated leapt the parapet – and our barrage caught him. The bombardment that commenced later seems to be more from the Ypres section, and now, after the rain, etc., still beating on.

148.

The first paper today for three or four days, dated Sep. 3, the news of importance is that Ashe has re-dressed his Chou Chin Chow – and the 

Sep. 6

Philistines are on their hind legs judging from the five portraits of new dresses in the Daily Mail, their fantasy doesn't come up to the old dresses, principally Burmese in their style – an origin – and remembering the dresses of the "Women of the Desert" and other stunts it's hard to see just the points of objection.

Ashe answers their whingeings and dismisses them in a line as "absurd and hypocritical". Before the court of Basil & Les, we tried and judged the case. Ashe we congratulated – "you'll do us Diggers" and dismissed to the tune of "We are the Robbers of the Wood".

If the Philistines want to roar let them do their roaring at their stinking Revues and their dirty insinuations.

149. Sept. 7

11.30 p.m. Frank brought in tonight late a letter from Erskine Macdonald to M.F. subscribers 1st editions of the Soldier Poet are available. "From an Outpost" of Coulson is a bonzer in the collection, and we read it first by the embankment at Bullecourt early last May – read it between carries. The second part of the Bullecourt stunt, when Billy was in Blighty, Scotty buried in a shell hole by the R.A.R. and young Monty on his way to Blighty. I was odd man. Then emergency dresser, guide & runner, coming back each time through the valley of the Dead Coulson Outpost poem and "The Hound of Heaven" kept my mind from the shells. Getting back each time through that smashed narrow sap
Entry.57:
over and over again, the first verse of 'The Hound' I spoke to myself. Taking any of the wounded walkers down was all right, then you weren't game to shew you were windy, but coming back was murder.

150. Sept. 8

Petit Sec Bois – with the Ambulance again - Motor Amb. from C.C.S. to Billets. Mail of Literature – Masefield's "Lollingdon Downs", addressed Y.M.C.A., A.I.F., B.E.F., France, Swinburne's 'Song of Italy' the first edition from Bakers', Birmingham, and the parcel from Hendersons – including copies 2, 3, 4 of "Today" which promise a jolly fine Rag, will subscribe.

151.

A match against the 3rd Batt. French Motors - the prettiest game imaginable, two teams of brown Pagans in the best of nick. Joe and Nick played a good game. J. especially so. Tomorrow move to take up a M.D.S.

152.
Entry.58:
Dickebusch, M.D.S.

Up and away from Petit Sec Bois by 7 a.m. In motor lorries A and C Sections to Dickebusch, and we take over the M.D.S. from the Tommies.

The afternoon half through, half of Swinburne's "Song of Italy" and No. 2 Issue of 'Today' mostly read, and I've finished reading. As yet only a few detailed to duties.

About 2 the Bosch was over – in a formation of 9 planes. Bombs he dropped all round us – about 10 in all, though they were small they did disastrous work, men and not guns suffered. 40 bad cases we dressed here, the of dead in the billet about 200 yds. across grass.

Two of warr's terrible Ironies – one Tommy who had served his full sum of years in the Army – tonight to leave for a discharge in Blighty – killed, and another, going on leave – he's right hand blown to bloodied flesh hanging on broken bones.

Sept. 9
Entry.59:
153.

The Book list stands now – Masefield's "Lollingdon Downs", Dunsany's Plays of Gods & Men", Hugo's of Iceland", Swinburne's 'Song of Italy', Brooke's "Selected Poems", Keats, 3 numbers of "Today", Waugh's "Loom of Youth", St. Phillips "New Inferno" and Materlinck's "On Unity" , works of P. Pearse. Transport? Some with Bob Sommerville in one of the Ambulances, some with Mac in another, three with Frank Stone in the O.R. papers, and Swinburne & Brooke and 'To Day' I carried in the pack.

154. Sept. 10

To see that all patients get well 'fed up' – in the practical sense. Till the end of the week when our Brigade will be up there'll be mostly only Tommies through.

Shift 9 till 9 in the stunt. I'll be Dressing.

155. Sept. 10

Reading the afternoon – the day brilliant and warr – quiet but for an occasional lazy beat of a high plane, or the sudden great whineing cry of a shell falling somewhere behind us – Masefield's Sonnet of Beauty in his Lollingdon Downs, and a play of Dunsany's, "The Laughter of The Gods", and "The Queen's Enemies". The designing of costumes and settings to one of his plays offers fascination. Ashe could do them well – but they're of a different atmosphere to his individual stuff – tho' their atmosphere is of the places he knows well. Barker could do them better. One of Ashe's in Chou Chin Chow was of Dunsany's though – a supremely simple and lovely design, she was a slave – beautiful and wounderful. Her hair was white – high dressed closely

the broad forehead sweep, a great bulging 'beehive' dressing she wore – a great white woollen cloak wrapt round her lovely glistening shoulders, and held over her breasts. This whiteness and beauty were exquisite.

156.
Entry.60:
He's an "I'm as good as any of them!" type, yet he's full of a pseudo vivaciousness that, effeminate though it is, is only tolerantly held as funny, in the old life he was – report has it – a 'Dancing Master'. He is an animated marionette happy to laugh with you, when you'll laugh at him, and I've to split the 24 hours working with him, he is annoyed in the Methodist fashion already with me – to give bread sop to good patients seems unnecessary – even though they'll be hungry and done out. His stalwarts around like flies round the buffet & affect an exclusiveness in their speaking. Hoboes of the "deeply-stupid-in-Hoboism" type.

The day's been perfect though, of reading I've done nothing, all the cases through are gassed by the new mustard gas & have to be dressed with care, the dresser wearing both gloves and Box helmet.

We've lost our surface dug-out. I'm sleeping behind the O.R. with Frank. No Mail.

157.
Entry.61:
Ten Bosch planes over the station this afternoon. Anti air craft guns shooting, ROTTON.

Cases through constantly till now - mid afternoon - and all gassed by the new terrible mustard gas shell.

158. Sept. 12

During one of the raids one night at Steenwerck, I started and half finished this – I finished it yesterday.

Night Raid Impression.

From round the horizon searching line of light pierces into night starred skies. 

Faintly down the darkness runs the beating of a swift machine. Remorselessly the pale fantastick fingers move slowly up and down, up, over and across. 

Of an instant, dully, viciously, a near gun vomits its shell and a rigid white gleaming moth lives leprous in the light.

Round starkly mounted guns stiff nerved bodies relax.

The gun wakes, her head lifts, 

Climbs higher, across and up.

A dull heavy overture of shells speed heavily high.

Gold sudden flashes in the night,

And the hollow whip of their death.

The machine guns match their elated chorus.

A thousand feet high, a touch releases an impatient compacted hell.

A great sweep and a rushing whirl as it turns to earth.

Follows another, and two more.

"Thank Christ the billet's thatched!

Did you hear those bloody ."

Slowly the living beating dies down the night.

And the faint tired drum – fire of a starting by Ypres drags on and on.

Today posted a copy – "The Vanity of Vanities" - to "Today" – with 10 Francs on a year's sub. to include the 1st copy.

159. Sept. 12

Last night Tom Davis blew in and we spent an hour yarning in the Buffet, the first I've seen of him since one day in Oct. when we had lunch at the stores, both in new uniforms, last Oct. twelve months.

160.

Reading "Lollingdon Down", John Masefield – I started out crossing the corners of pages whose sonnets fully appealed, now I've stopped it, merely in crossing of every page. Today I wrote to Bakers for "Martin Hyde" and Masefield's "An English Prose Miscellany". Later I'll get the others he quoted for – Gallipoli, 10/- and 'Capt. Margaret', 9/-.

161.

A jolly nice little letter to night from "Your old Auntie Louis". Of some of the 'bonzer' little women of the world she is one.

The two books – Davidson & Watson arrived well.

162.Sept. 12

Some day I'll have a finely designed case of books – there'll be 1st editions only and books of some fineness. There'll be Meredith's "Ordeal of Richard Feveral", Hardy's "Jude the Obscure", McKenzies "Sinister Street", Barrie's "Half Hours", Pater's "Imaginary Portraits" & "Marius the Epicurean". Poetry by Masefield, Brooke, Swinburne & Keats – and certainly Leslie Coulson's "From an Outpost". There'll be something of Symons, perhaps and Wilde's "Intention" and "Dorian Gray", and on Symond's Italian essays if I can get them.

Oh God for the quietness of home and books.

A cabinet – in the print cabinet style for Mags. & literary Rags would be a rather interesting collection.

163.
Entry.62:
Today my birthday: the 21st in Liverpool, 22nd at Wimereux, and the 23rd – today – at Dickebusch in Belgium, the 24th?

Presents to myself – an order to Bakers for Masefield's "Martyn Hyde" and "An English Prose Miscellany", and 40F. to Mayhew on account of 8 books he's putting aside, and from him the first edition of John Drinkwater's "Olton Pools".

164.

Now I've just finished the reading of Dunsany's new book – "Plays of Gods & Men". Four plays in all make up the book, published by Fisher Unwin, printed in Dublin. The first two are good – the second fully up to the standing of the plays in the book I bought in Edinburgh for 3/6, and catalogued S.H. by Baker at 18/-. That book "Plays" is infinitally the book in which Dunsany's merit will be founded. "The Laughter of the Gods" is a tale of the vengeance of the Gods, a false prophecy from the lips of their priests, became the truth, and the town is annihilated.

The third play, "The Tents of the Arabs" I skipped – but read the last spoken lines,

"I will raise up my head of a night time against the sky, and the old, old, unbought stars shall twinkle through my hair, and we shall not envy any of the diademmed Queens of the world."

Of Synge all I have read is "Deidre", this of Dunsanys is somewhat in his manner.

Sept. 13

"The Night at the Inn" is simply a rather an unique juggling with the ideas in "The Gods of the Mountains".

Today cold and dull, a rotten, rotten, day, reading was taboo, and work slack.

This afternoon the 20 Batt. passed in Battle order, B Company of the Ambulance left Petit Sec Bois, and are expected here tomorrow. Wrote to Mother, this time a letter I'll post.

This afternoon full of restless desires, and longings, for everything millions of miles from war and its ideas. Damn, Damn!! Damn!!!

165.
Entry.63:
A mail in late last night – so I'd some home letters on my birthday. One from Mother, July 8 and from Billy the same date and of the good ones one from Mrs. Curtiss, July 8 too. Only two letters have I received from Mrs. Curtiss, and both very touching notes, full of real love and emotion.

The rest of the mail barren stuff – full of hypocritical endearment, funny almost in their smugness, one in particular after a page of written "sympathy" going to news, bemoans the attendance of physically fit at picture shows and theatres, damns those who "fail to do their duty". Father declined an invitation to that man's son's wedding last year, and his son is still one of the fit shirkers.

Geoff going for 6 months to some farm. I don't understand it at all but from the Mother's letter his eyes are bad and he'll continue his course next year.

166. Sept. 14

In the autumn announcements of Sept. 6 Times Literary Supplement appears a Swinburne notice. Messrs. Heinemann have acquired all his copyright – and anticipate publishing après la guerre a definite edition of verse & prose. In the meantime his unpublished Posthumous stuff in printing & will include the early publication of two vols. of letters, also a cheap pocket edition of sacred 'Poems & Ballads' and other vols.

This morning I've been reading the press notices the first series of his "Poems & Ballads" received: at the back, & between end page of "The Song of Italy" are a fair number of contemporary criticisms. They form in themselves a compared to "Art & Morality" of Mason – or Wilde's "Picture of Dorian Gray".
Entry.65:
167.

A long day of solid going for all hands. Thirteen Bosch planes over this morning – as usual the shooting – "Moody!" Bombs dropped accounted for half the morning's dressings, then big batches – 10 to 40 at times of gassed kept the ball rolling.

No bombardment yet started but rumours still run wild.

Tonight I got my Keats back – from the B Section Bin of the O. papers.

Last night Nick brought over two cuttings from Sydney's papers of the Dad's funeral, he is dead three months today.

168. Sept. 16

In the line the bombardment started now with a vengeance – either tonight or tomorrow the Bearers go up. The hour's about 11 and already we've had a full squadron of 16 Bosch planes

Sept. 16

over, they turned directly above us, and made back, shooting good for a while, but directly they'd banked well together it turned dry. Two enormous planes kept well amongst the others, but the gods of the Kaiser protected them. Anti air craft shooting is an absolute dud – except for pulling up a turning barrage, the planes today were so low that their compleat crosses could be easily seen.

169.

Last night a photograph from Toby, the supper a success.

170.

In this morning's orders, Kirchner pronounced anathema, and "La Vie Parisienne" declared beyond the pale.

In a word – trading with the French in indecent pictures and literature is forbidden. The 'indecent pictures' referred to are of the French – photographs of the nude – and of beautiful courtesans certainly, so beautiful that only rarely can the terrible word 'indecent' be used towards them, but the literature! Considering the only doubtful literature sold to the Troops by the Frenchies comes from well established London publishers, this order is quite in keeping with their damned hypocrisy and pettiness.

171.

Today's mail – one letter from Mrs. Hadley. I'll send to her for keeping now Swinburne's "Song of Italy" and Masefield's "Lollingdon Downs", later then to "Auntie Louis" the "Works of Padraic Pearse" & "Earth or Cualaan".

If the twenty note I'm carrying now is unbroken by next pay, to Bakers I'll send 15 for A.C. Benson's "Upton Letters" & Swinburne's 3rd series of 'Ballads'.

Sept. 16

172.

An hour since A and B Bearers left for the line. Tomorrow the remainder go in, and on Tuesday the stunt of stunts starts.

There's a destiny in the air, and a peculiar half hidden elation, the Battle will be ours – they'll take all their objectives, and the bloody price paid will bring new stars into Australian Heavens. Christ God help them!

Again the little rising sun will be the badge of another tragic success, there's high tragedy to be acted now, and the actors are Australians. An exultation will carry them through – an overpowering exultation that will bear a passion of fighting, and there'll trickle through the station a thousand tattered and warr wounded – their wounds ranging from shrapnell scratches to torn off legs and arms, and ripped bodies – a thousand who have made history super-splendid for a country young to fame.

At Bullecourt I kissed in the dark an old bronze badge – out of passion of love for those who owned it.

The night's rich in blue colour, and the tents are black silhouettes against a dark sky of a faintly lit horizon. The gun's lightning is quick and faint.

173. September 17

Mother's birthday today.

Its dull and there's a promise of rain in the windy sky, and the cold's coming over again, the early days of the winter seem looming darkly ahead.

Sept. 17

174.

Syd was 'up' this morning: yesterday afternoon being in Pop. he was too late back to camp to go up the line, seeing he had the impertinence while we were at Henencourt to apply for his second stripe – after service since the beginning, being wounded, the M.M. at Factory Corner, and being generally depended on in a hundred military ways by the M.O. and half the non coms. A L/Cpl., so!

175. 

- and working next to us now, some of the 7th Field under Maj. Conrick, D.S.O. of Bullecourt, at the 2nd General last year he was one of the wardens, and with the 7th he's the "Butcher", and the damnable part of the whole concern is that by the people at home their decorations mean only wondour and work that has counted.

Sept. 17

Sept. 18

175.

The evening's colder than the morning promised: the stunt hasn't yet commenced, and a half hour ago a few rain drops fell. Another train load of bombs has just passed the station, and today Tom Richards through the D. Room, briefly outlined the stunt's objectives. Already two of our bearers have been knocked – report has it, Algy and Jim Mitchell.

Tomorrow?

Through the station today there's been a fairly steady flow, but nothing like the expected rush that will mean the stunting.

176. September 18

Jim Downie, Freddy Flowers and Nic, killed in action. Wounded, badly, Sgt. Reid – in the abdomen, he left here in a very low condition, and 

Sept. 18

the doubt was whether he'd reach the C.C.S. Matthews – Matty is in the Resuscitation tent now. Knocked in the head, and arms, shoulders and legs, he's lost a deal of blood, but his chances of pulling through are good. Toby and Nick – both 'cushy' wounds – probable Blighties. Also young George Cochrane, and the Sentimental Bloke – good Blighties. Stubbs, Lofty Owens, Ern Brown, Jack Bottger & Duval, Paddy O'Houllihan, and Robbins and Mulholland.

Two days in, and 22 casualties – three dead.

Midday now, and the morning's been quiet and even, a thin drizzly rain has helped to dam things, and the sky's full of unshed rain.

Jim Downing was ready this week to go on leave: Nic joined us up at Henencourt and this was his first time in.

Later. Sept. 18

Reid reached the C.C.S. and seemed better on arrival, it's a Canadian C.C.S., so his chances are good.

Nic few of the chaps here seem to remember: he was a tall slightly built young chap – perhaps not yet twenty, and this was his first stunt. Attached to the 2nd C.C.S. he was one of the night bearers, and the quickest of the crowd, always in the morning rushes gave one of us dressing a hand with the most difficult.

In A Section he had no particular friend – he played Cricket at Henencourt, and seemed particularly attached to no party.

Almost he was one of the Predestined of Materlinck's exquisite papers, "Predestination". And Jim Downing: an easy slow going bootmaker of Henencourt and Freddy? always reading.

Sept. 18

Freddy'd softly enquire, "What is it this time, Frank?, and he'd be interested when he had no sympathy with the matter.

4 p.m. Paddy dead and Sgt. Reid at the C.C.S.

Syd has gone down to see Erny.

These laid the world away: poured out the red 

Sweet wine of youth: gave up the years to be, 

Of work and joy, and that unhoped serene 

That men call age: and those who would have been,

Their sons, they gave, their immortality.

Blow, Bugles Blow!

In the cemetary by the station they buried the bodies of Freddy, Jimmy and Nic.

Tonight C Section Bearers go up, 6 p.m. The Col. and Syd back from the C.C.S. Ernie and Duval – Ernie penetrating wound chest, and Duval abdomen – both stand a chance of pulling through & Young a good chance, a lot depending on himself. Nick and Toby and some of the others already entrained. Matti still here in the Resus. tent, and a 100% better.

The sky's clouds seem thinning – but the air's grey and cold.

177.

Tomorrow I'm to take over for the stunting the Resuscitation Tent. Thank Christ the days of mouthing "cheerful clear flat platitudes" are passed. Cheerfully serving Coffee to "Damaged Goods" when hell's delight is the day's orders would be rotten, and in the Resuscitation Tent I'll have a decent chance.

It's about 9.30, and the big bombardment started a while back. The sky's clearer and one long flicker makes it always bright.

Sept. 29, 20, 21

Sept. 21

178.

Sept. 19. Neilson died of wounds at A.D.S. and Syd Knight wounded.

Sept. 20. Only serious cases through the station and a stream all day. In the Resuscitation Tent and Les working there too. In the afternoon Tom from the Q.M.'s dept. in to give a hand with Mason - Bike orderly and O'Sullivan. The stream continued till early this morning, at 9 the tressles of the R.T. empty, and the Bow hut next to Dressing Room now used in its place.

The stunt?, seemingly it's been successful from the jump, but we've "no guts" since 9.

The day's magnificent, clear and a brilliant sun.

The curl round the 'a' in magnificent – from a starting at the opening up of the anti air craft gun alongside the station.

179. Sept. 21

Somebody a while ago used the phrase, "a picture no artist can paint", there's one subject only, one man has been remotely successful at 'War!', the man is Raemaeker, and of his remembered cartoons the one that holds some of its big horror is the one of the living demented woman amongst her murdered dead – she kneeling over the ravished body of a young girl.

'War' – as a stark splendid youth in a great charge, stately marching over heaped dead is the sentimentalist's idea of a force he only imagines.

As a figure of Death carelessly scything long ranks of men, there is only an imagined side. Bloodiness, sheer horror and torn parts of men, futile agony and pity. War cannot be fastened on canvas as the other forces.

 Bert Reynolds latest knocked. near end of book.

Sept. 21

180.

The rumour comes down that two more of the Ambulance have been killed and six wounded. Nothing yet been heard of Ernie's or Young's condition, the last heard was of a favourable progression.

Tonight Tim down to the station and an hour's walking up and down the road that runs by us. Talking of many things and casualty – and we with few late subjects of old interest. Blighty and Amiens and the Somme, and of the men who make up a unit.

The coming night gave us – or provided the perfect background, for a display from a Bosch plane. Secretly he came over – and fired into one of our baloons, a long lovely pillar of darkening smoke from a lurid gold flame, and a million pale and brilliant stars, a fantastick Pogany - with the bright colourings of Branguin.

Three times during the day, fleets of his planes have come over, by report they dropped bombs by Hill Corner.

181. Sept. 22

A fourth raid about 9.30 last night – and a dump caught a few miles across from us, burnt till we tired of watching it, some of the cases through here – about 7 in all, six killed outright. Cloudy sky holds today – but bright otherwise, quiet generally.

Mail – one receipt from Mayhew, and word of his seeking for Drinkwater's Olton Pools". Parcelled up for Mrs. Hadley, Song of Italy and Masefield's Lollingdon Downs and for 'Auntie Louis' The New Inferno and Dunsany's book of plays.

Sept. 23-24-25

Steenvoorde

182. Sept. 25

To Steenvoorde from Dickebusch on Sept. 23rd by M.T. lorries. Billeted about 2 kilos outside the village, in the centre of lovely fields, in a group of thatched farmhouses. Writing this before 9.30 parade – down one of the roads comes a column of our Infantry, brought down from the line by Transports, and resting till the end of the week.

The rich male musick of a bugle band plays their time. As men they're again the splendid types they were last year.

From casual report our casualties have been wounderfully light, while those of the Bosch have been correspondingly high, and they took all their objectives – and could have taken more. We are expecting to move up again at the end of the week – to take over the A.D.S. Then there'll be stunting again, the 1st Brigade will be in again.

Turning in last night Frank and Basil & self yarning – on a subject now generally taboo – taboo seemingly because of the distance to be gone before the ending.

The warr, the conditions internally and in the line of the Bosch, of the Porters, of the Tommies, and of ourselves. It was a delivering of opinions – personal – of the attitudes to be adopted towards the Bosch 'Apres la Guerre'.

Personally I cannot yet place my own attitude, I 'clutch at shadows, Cry, and cannot tell'.

Always the art of Building, of Decoration, and of Architecture as practised by the Bosch till 1914, have irresistibly appealed, have appealed even on the highest and most perfect periods of English Art, and certainly they have evolved out of the centuries' styles, a unique and most fitting modern style, here France cannot attempt

to compete with her.

England? England's Architectural Arts and Buildings remain distinctive and high, but she owes a very great deal to Germany. Witness one of the highest forms of Art – the Art of the Theatre, there to Germany England owes enormously, though repays her debt by her loan of Shakespeare.

183.

Yesterday's mail brought Copies 1, 6 & 7 of "To-Day", the day before's Masefield's 'Martin Hyde' and his Anthology of English Prose – with his introduction. 'Martin Hyde' I started immediately – Stevenson and Conrad on a shelf with this of Masefield. Three masters of the Romance of Adventure, and each with his own individual style.

Last night Bosch planes over somewhere about Steenvoorde bombing, here we heard about half a dozen crumps then hideous elation.

184. Sept. 25

"Ah, Snowy's gone to No. 2 Aust. General Hospital –"

"Who 'as!"?

"Maclure!"

"That's a --!"

"Where is it: Rouen ain't it!"

"No Blighty!"

"No its at Abbeville – or that's No. 3!"

"What's 'e gone there for –"

"—to have a – good time! wish I could get there.

"Ow'd he manage it!"

"He's got a brother there who's claimed 'im!"

"Wish to Christ I 'ad one of those brothers in a cushy job!"

"And so his knoll is knolled."

A golden haired young lithe pagan full of the joy of the sun, and with a taste for the voluptuous wonder of Ancient Greece.

"I bet Mac's drunk before he – well leaves 'ere!"

"The lucky --!"

Sept. 25

185.

The Billets are old thatched Farmhouses built along the short side of a great rich grass'd tree bounded paddock: at the opposite side to the Farmhouse, 500 yards down, a stream runs across the paddock: at one place the stream has been dug out on either of its banks and a great willow lined pool breaks the stream. That is our bathing place. This afternoon Mac has left for the 2nd: the entry, 184, I wrote on hearing just as he'd left the Billet to parade to O.R. To the Billet it was one of the Transport chaps that brought the first suntan.

The afternoon lovely for writing – for a walk to the ridge that dominates our plain, where the town of Cassel is built. Or even to the village of Steenvoorde to see nearby the church, its fretted spire rising from the rich brick tower.

But my ankle's in plaster coils, so I'm by the bathing pool. The footballers are between myself and the Billet, and their shorts and Guernseys would make the high Gods weep.

I've again my "From a College Window" of A.C. Bensons. Bus brought it into the D.R. at Dickebusch just as we were leaving, and Darcy carried it with my library to here.

In one week I've lost three of my best friends – Nick, Toby, and today Mac. Harold will get to Blighty but it will be only with a lot of luck. Toby will follow him.

No mail today. One letter dated July 15 yesterday from Mother.

Read "The Simple Life", A.C. Benson.

Sept. 26

186.

Joined up the unit again, Bill Dunn, Jack Maddox – both wounded at Vaux and Bullecourt last May, and 'Hunter' (Underwood) from the C. Cadet School.

187.

Last night walked with Frank into Steenvoorde: waited in the queue of the Kookaburras for a half hour and with a long line turned away. Then walked through the square – listened a while to one of the Brigade Bands.

The town full of the 1st Divisioin, and they all looking splendid. They're tanned by the summer sun, and in wounderful nik from a heavy training of three months behind the Somme. Added, their success and few casualties in the beginning of the stunt that's still on, have immensely bucked them.

Every estaminet, shop and eating house was crowded. Met there one of our chaps who had left us at Henencourt as an A.M.C. detail to one of the Artillery Batteries, he now detail to 1st Divy. Signallers.

Then to the church. The Tower of old fine now wearing bricks richly rising from its clustering houses of large-tiled roofs. Against the pale sky, enclosing the town, down the road with the tower rising from directly our front, there was in its design all the quaintness of a Samuel Prout lithograph. The fretted spire not in keeping, and spoiling in the effect. The church itself hidden out of proportion by the Tower, seems new. Its design inside rather fine, and certainly unique. The old cross plan survives, but its trancepts shallow. The

Sept. 26

white stone pillars at the crossing, built evidently to support the lantern tower, support but a low of walling, that rises only 1' above the apex of each arch. The ceiling is vaulted, and line behind a timber ribbing. The effect is fine and unique. The High Altar ends in an apse, the Nave, and the Lady Altar and are of the aisles: the altar rail and steps enclose the three.

The windows are modern and of poor stained glass.

188.

Today we've our flag up, or rather England and the Red Cross. Why we are not permitted the working under our own starr'd flag beats me, and half the unit. Today wrote letter of six pages to Mother, and read "Martin Hyde". Its 'tres bonne!"

189. Sept. 26

No mail – posted to 'Aunt Louis' Padraic Pearse "Works" and "Earth of Cualaan". Two books of Maunsells, that of Padraic Pearse full to each of its covers of beauty and loveliness.

190.

Today green envelope, Norm Reed used to give them to our section – he's dead.

He only joined us up at Henencourt, and in a month had taken Cliff's place. We lost Cliff to B. Section, and cursed them accordingly. Then came Norm Reed. He was a big chap, finely built – a larger edition of Jake, with all his pagan grace, with all his vitality and character. He filled Cliff's place so well we followed him willingly, and in every way he was 'one of us'.

He was of the type that

Sept. 26

has given all the honour to Australia's name, and he's dead. His white cross in some cramped graveyard, by the dead of the stunting and past stunting is another part of the "glorious pageantry of wounderful war".

If these damned preachers who preach this a "cleansing warrr" could be brought face to face with a sap of shell'd dead, their mouthings full of God's name would wither on their thin lips.

And Paddy, Paddy with the heart of a girl child, the tenderness and love of a woman, and the stubborn soul of a martyr. On leave last year he was married, took as his honeymoon 17 days 'without leave' – and did 21, 1st F. punishment. Here in the unit his irresponsible nature and stubbornness not being admitted by authority, he was a typical case of the chap of worth at his work, but 'up against' authority – authority that is here in the Army every bit as bad as any Bosh militarism.

Reports up to today report Ernie and Duval still hanging on. Ernie with some improvement. A thousand times I've cursed him silently in my mind, when we've been in some hot position, but his coolness and unnatural calm has always had its effect, and we've owed our lives to him.

An original of the Ambulance, and having sufficient character to believe in his own experience against the knowledge of the vacuum, decorated by three stars, and bearing till he was knocked, not till Bullecourt did he get the M.M.

Sept. 26

At Factory Corner last Feb. he was hauled over the coals for taking the saving of a man's life into his hands.

At the R.A.P., and a new newly arrived newly fledged, by university examination, doctor! – a child wearing three stars with the experience of medical practice afforded by a six weeks transport across the Indian Ocean.

Two Inf. chaps were both badly caught at the Sunken Road below Headquarters by a shell. Ernie got his squad across to them, dressed them both, and put on the stretcher the one most alive: the other was smashed about the head, shoulders and had his guts protruding.

They started to carry across to the R.A.P., and met the M.O. (?) coming across to them in a fury: his demands were why they'd not sent Regimental to bring them to the post – why they'd dared to dress them without he first seeing them, why they'd dared judge the condition of the men and place one before the other.

Ernie was polite: stuck to his ideas, and carried on.

That Captain's ? charge was impertinence and Ernie's unreliability.

In a stunt that newly arrived M.O., if his Battalion suffers sufficiently heavily will get the Military Cross. Regimental and his Medical Details will win it for him, he never will.

And the Sydney University has shortened the Medical Course and now her machined turned 'Doctors' are arriving here to divest of its last shread the hideous skeleton of the old Doctor puppet lie.

Sept. 26

191.

Writing before turning in.

Hancock just bowled over from across the billet with a white satin square, centrely painted in lurid flames the tower and a part of the building of the Cloth Hall of Ypres. Encircling it a wreathing of pale pink and veau rose roses and foliage. Compleating the satin were two rows of lace, rather coarse but apparently hand made: in the four corners of the first row were tied seven blue baby ribbon bows.

This work of art cost him at Steenvoorde 20 Francs: my opinion as to its artistic qualities in comparison with the price were asked.

In Egypt – in the Wassah in the even as in the principle street the Arabs sold similar pieces of embroidery and painting on lurid blatant satins. Here, and in the Somme region the Flemish and French sell the troops the identical articles, cushion covers, scarfs and small 'embroidered' post cards.

Their colours are primary for the most part, and their golden inscriptions of the 'Love to Mother' and 'Remember Me' type. They are 'Souvenirs of France' – 'of Albert' – 'of Cairo' and 'of Belgium'. Their subjects are bunches of the Allies Flags, of rustic farmhouses, of Pansies, and floral designs.

They would be great trading articles with primitive peoples, and the traffic in them is appaling. To let them

Sept. 26

having been sent home by 80% of the A.I.F. – sent home with an innocent belief in their beauty – would be safe and sure.

A hundred times I've been asked to deliver judgment. I'd have given worlds to have done so on their , but I've cheerfully lied as the way out, and have saved my name as one who understands the elements of Taste.

192.

After 6 with Brooke's Selected Verse and No. 4 of 'To Day' for a walk by the Billets scattered by the farmhouses, along the white wandering roads that lead far away places by timid ways.

The reading I kept till I'd arrived back at Billets, then I read a review of Ralph Hodgsons new book of Poems. I have written to the Book Dept. of To Day for a copy – enclosing 5 Francs to buy a 3/6 book.

193. Sept. 27

No Mail.

A 'Flemish fine day', the country as depicted in all the old Flemish paintings, calm and neatly outlined.

Some of the new reinforcements today arrive, and Harold Long amongst them, a friendship to be taken up after a barren break of almost ten years.

Yarning to Steenvoorde with him. Straight from Australia after 18 months – or 15 at Nelson Island. D.H. Detailing him to the Bearers, but as yet to no particular section. Potato picking morning and afternoon, and from half a loaf of freshly baked bread.

Sept. 27

194.

The 4th and 5th Divisions have – report here this morning – taken all their objectives in the advance and with small casualties. The A.D.S. seems to be still suffering, and the 8th have lost 4 killed & 28 wounded, similarly to our big batch of the 18th. Then the report, our bearers went in again two days ago, no report of them. The 2nd lost one of their Ambulance cars at the culvert from the A.D.S.

And the A.D.S. is ours when we next go in, report next Sunday.

Laus Deo.

195.

Frank last night shewed me a cable from – the information of it to go to Syd Woollems. His father dead, and he anxiously waiting word of Ernie, his sister's husband.

There'll be agony of mind for him when he hears, and a terrible woundering that it's some mistake, and there'll be no quiet fields and white sunken road for him to wander in, holding his misery and his mind the other side of the world. He's with the bearers, in the line, at the A.D.S. or about Ypres.

In a dugout at Flers last December I first heard him mention his father – 'the Dad', and it was in connection with his having received his expected commission – "Wouldn't the old Dad be proud". And he's dead.

196. September 28

At 4 this morning the Col. up to the advanced area, to look out the position of the new A.D.S. we're to open up.

Sept. 28

197.

First I noticed him between his pair of horses at Dickebusch.

He was new to the Transport. Then I saw him here our first day in Billets. Two Flemish girls selling chocolate had found his identification disc, called his name at the Barn doorways.

His thanks to the girls were shy, they were offered with a colouring up and he was embarrassed.

Only in fatigues dress I've seen him – Kharki slacks, creased so they're no looseness, a brown cardigan, & his bracers over it, his hat badged and turned at the side – a slouch hat of a landsman. He leaves the impression of a country lad, well burned by the sun a rich warm colour, well featured and quiet, broad shouldered and well built from the hips, his ugly slacks contradict his legs building.

Sept. 28

Sept. 29

Then yesterday, I saw him at the stream, stripped in the warm sun, flinging buckets of the stream water over his horses. He was rich in his build, and with the horses, the sun and green grass, a wounderful type – typical of Australia's country, of her colour and of her beauty. He's a number and a Driver in the A.S.C.

198. Sept. 29

De Profundis, the word's our morning up most likely tomorrow: from last night word will be any hour from the A.D.M.S., and we for the A.D.S., advanced to the Bosch old country and close to the wood – West Hoek.

Late last night – Frank and self to Cassel in the afternoon & back to camp late – word of 5 more of the bearers knocked – Pullen, Croden, Squires, Piam & another – the chap who exchanged

Sept. 29

with Mac.

This the last page of my third journal, the 4th to start with the last quarter, a bright moon and the A.D.S. amongst the guns – more than usual. My luck's held now for ten months – and the stunts – Flers – Factory Corner, the Yarra Bank, Luisenhof Farm, Ligney Thilloy and La Barque – Doignies Hermies – and Bullecourt. I've come through clean.

199.

One of the white ducks over to pick up our breakfast scraps – a white duck, with a faint tinging through clean feathering of old ivory. The colour of her feathers for the walls, gold Chinese Brocade hangings to windows, a small casted Victory stained orange-Vermillion standing on a black basalt pedestal – olive green rugs, and three nocturne paintings of Syd Long, and a few designs by Thea Proctor.

200. Sept. 27

The guns last night, early this morning and now – 8.15 a.m., heavily incessant, booming without cessation, and to here the bark of the 18 pounder won't carry. "Did you hear there's a – war on?" from a Transport the minute back, which led to this entry.

201.

Mail midday – letter from Harold – from No. 5 Hut Cambridge Hospital, Aldershot, and he doing well, 'a bonzer Doctor, and fine sisters', from T.B.C. "The City of Fear" Frankau and from C. Bank word of their paying to to Robbie's account £5. Sept. 3rd I wrote for "The City of Fear" – with Drinkwater's book of essays. Since then I've written for one of Ledwidge's, one of Seeger and "Letters of a Soldier". These are still missing.

Ends the journal started at Henencourt and completed at Steenvoorde in Flanders resting from the first stunting of the Menin Road Battle.

War Office letters

Quaint Correspondence

Those concerned with the payment of separation allowances receive some weird letters. The following were received by the London authorities –

Dear Sir – My husband has been away at the Crystal Palace, and got four days furlong, and has now gone to the Mind Sweepers – Yrs. respectfully.

Dear Sir – I have received your letter. I am his Grandfather & Grandmother: he was born and brought up in this house in answer to your letter. Yrs. truly.

Dear Sir – I am writing these few lines for Mrs. Morgan, she cannot write herself. She is expecting to be confined and can do with it.

Dear Sir. Mrs. Haynes has been sent to bed with a little lad. Wife of Peter Haynes. I am etc.

Dear Sir. In accordance with instructions on ring paper, I have given birth to a daughter on April 21st. Yours etc.

(Note – the Ring paper is a paper given by the Gvt., to women drawing separation allowances, and it is stamped with a circular stamp giving date of last payment.)

Dear Sir. You have changed my little boy into a girl. Will it make any difference. Yrs. truly.

Dear Sir. I am expecting to be confined next month. Will you please tell me what I am to do about it? Yours. etc.

Dear Sir. My Bill has been put in charge of a Spitoon, shall I get any more pay?

Aug. 25. The Kaiser's committed suicide! 'Again?' – and (again). Lens has fallen.

Aug. 26. The unit's going back for more training! The Australian fighting here is purely a blind to make Fritz imagine this is our permanent address.

Aug. 27. Leave open again after three days closing of it. So the Americans are over at last.

Aug. 30. Att. to the 2nd Army were to go out for a six months rest, but again Birdwood with his 5 Divisions is going to have a smack at Lille. Leave closed again.

Sept. 1. 1, 2nd Divisions for Ypres front this coming week, 2, 4, 5 for the Somme.

Sept. 2. The warr's over (only fighting continues).

Sept. 5. Riga has fallen to the Bosch.

Sept. 13. Stunting like hell starts tomorrow!

Sept. 16. Now not till tomorrow, Tommies want to know if it's a fact that the non success of this stunt means our turning the game in. Well yes, our failure would.
